First of all the taco salad is quite hefty, so that's a plus.  The dressing they use is really good and they evenly coat all the lettuce with it before adding the toppings.  Beans, pico, meat, and guac, heartily cover the entire top portion so they aren't skimping.  The carnitas isn't too fatty or tough, so that's always great.  The guac tastes homemade and not like something out of a bargain store's refrigerated section so that's also great.  

Service is pretty fast.  The woman taking my order is always friendly.  And the workspace seems pretty clean.  

In all, I'd be willing to branch out and try other options, but if you're a fan of a good tostada/taco salad, you'll probably be happy with TacoBar's offering.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: From their amazing specialty margaritas to their great selection of tacos this place was awesome. I asked about the spice level and they automatically suggested putting it on the side and adding as I wanted. They have fun card games to practice Spanish and the vibe is very friendly.
author: Nikolina V.

description:
Whoa, TacoBar exceeded all of our expectations. Just order the Baja pescado TACO ESPECIAL style, and you'll know what I mean. The melted cheese outer shell was such a perfect addition to a well fried fish taco. 

You know what? i think it's better than Nick's! (Bold statement right?)
author: Joanna S.

description: It was my first time here. If were to describe the energy of this place Id say fresh. The energy is moving and its positive. It might have been the time I walked in I think they just opened but the whole place was really clean and EVERYONE was super good vibes and willing to help with anything. The food was fresh and really tasty!! The owner and the staff here have all around good vibes and I like it! Definitely will be back! THANK YOU! :)
author: Sue S.

description: I'm really torn on how to rate TacoBar. Part of me wants to give it a five, and parts of me wants to give a three, so naturally I'll just settle at four stars. I got a chicken quesadilla, and it was incredible. Really good grilled chicken inside, a ton of delicious cheese, and cooked to perfection. I also decided to try the Baja Pescado Burrito and it didn't live up to the same expectations I had set from eating the quesadilla. The fish just tasted bad :( I really really wanted to love the burrito as much as the quesadilla but I think the fish was bad! Unfortunate.
author: Clay P.

description: I can't figure out why this place is reviewed so low - it's totally awesome. Clean, great atmosphere, awesome burritos & friendly staff. It's been a neighborhood staple of mine for years.
author: Jeanna B.

description:
Meh not impressed. I can get better tasting Mexican food from my local Taco truck in the east bay for a fraction of the price. 

Your wallet will cry from the outrageously priced menu. The fact that they don't offer free chips with your entree kills me. 

The food and service aren't too shabby. I've had better elsewhere. Unfortunately, there aren't any alternatives so I'll be back so long as I'm prepared to burn a whole in my pocket.
author: Cloak Dagger O.

description:
I visited this restaurant on 19 June 2012 while on vacation in San Francisco.

After reading other reviewers of Taco Bar, I have to wonder if we ate at the same restaurant.

Overall, the food is very good. I had two of the pulled pork tacos, which were a special the day I was there. The tacos were on your standard size corn tortilla, like you would find in any local supermarket. Another reviewer mentioned that the tortillas were three inches, mine clearly were not. The pork, which was topped by a small amount of citrus marinated onions,  was tender, tasty, plentiful and clearly of excellent quality. It was not something that you would see in a cheaper taco and wonder what part of the pig it came from. Each taco was $3.25, and in my opinion worth it. After I was finished eating a a man that I think was the chef came to my table. He was very friendly and recommended the coconut flan. It was as good as he said it would be. It was a denser flan, not jello-like in consistency, and very good. 

Other reviewers mentioned the small portions that one gets at the Taco Bar. After scoping out what the other patrons were eating and seeing the size of my tacos and flan, I have to wonder again if we were eating at the same restaurant.

Another reviewer mentioned that this place is "deceptive". I didn't find it so, but if you are doubtful about this place just check out a menu and look around at what others are eating. When I was there the place was very crowded and busy, a deceptive place wouldn't have such a crowd I would think.

As for the price, I believe it was fair, given the quality of the food and the quick and friendly service. 

I found the food at Taco Bar food to be authentic. I come from Los Angeles and have a good idea as to what good Mexican food is thanks to my Mexican friends, colleagues and students. 

This place is worth your time and cash, check it out, you won't be sorry.
author: Ralph I.

description:
Have been here consistently for the past year or so and never had a miss. Though I tend to trust Yelp, this is one of the places that definitely deserves much more credit than they have here. I don't get the 3 star rating. 

Their meat is always tender, juicy, fresh and flavorful, both for the burritos and for the tacos. They tend to be very generous with it and pack a good amount of it in their food. 

The produce is fresh, they mastered the point of their rice, and the beans are never too soft nor too hard. Just right. TacoBar has definitely done a great job with their food. 

Their portions are extremely generous, so if you still have some space, DON'T miss the Churros. They are perfectly crunchy on the outside, smooth inside, with a bit of cream, and some cinnamon and sugar to top it. 

Now on the service part, which is half of the experience. The people are super helpful, kind, and nice. Authentic Latin American service. Honest, friendly, and efficient service.


Great spot, will keep coming.
author: Daniel S.

description: Stopped in for a light lunch.  The fresh lime Margaritas were refreshing but light on the booze.  High point was the fresh chips and yummy Cameron tacos.  Fresh fresh fresh.  My sister had a ceaser salad.   All very good.  Outside seating was a nice touch too.  Recommend for a quick fast meal.
author: Celeste S.

description: Meh, nothing exciting. We had vegetarian tacos, sandwhich & nachos. Nothing to boast about, decently priced. Service & staff were really good & happy to help us. Their fresh juices are a must try, might come back for fresh watermelon juice.
author: Vipul Z.

description: Had a delicious pollo burrito with no beans and with the habanero sauce, my husband has the Baja Pescado with cheese and swears by it. The magaritas are also delicious. Definitely coming back. Ate the food too fast to take a picture.
author: Liz S.

description:
Bland chipotle tacos. I almost stood at the door and warned people about how expensive and bla the food is. Maybe it's the only Mexican food spot around and maybe no one around here knows what decent Mexican food should be. 

The basket of chips is insanely big and you pay for it. Plus they have no prices posted which leads me back to the expression, " if you have to ask how much it costs then you can't afford it."  Well in this case that's true. I can't afford 
Expensive mediocre Mexican food.

Two stars for having air plants(super trendy plants that do not require dirt) , nice employees and outdoor seating. 

Meh.....
author: Joseph M.

description: They serve breakfast! Nothing like having a vegetarian breakfast burrito with no pico de gallo and substitute the beans for refried beans and add guacamole, after a morning run. It's a pretty good size too. The Aguas Frescas are pretty fresh and not sweet, just thirst quenching and refreshing. Neighborhood gem.
author: leba g.

description: Taco Bar is really just an okay place. Has more of a franchise taste like high-tech burrito. Don't come in if your expecting a unique authentic taste, but do come in if you want a quick burrito, quesadilla, whatever. The service was so-so. Not that friendly nor off-putting. The space is cool if your coming alone or with a buddy, but not great for bigger groups since it only sits around 25 people at once. Got a carne asada quesadilla. Paid about 9.50 for it. Asked for chips but it's an additional 2$ so I said never mind, not worth it. Every other Mexican place I've been to gives chips for free. Portion size, again, was okay, but I've been to plenty of other taquerias ordering the same and received greater portion size. Not really complaining about any of this, just not a place I'd go to again unless I was really craving that type of food.
author: Jovinho B.

description:
Juicy carne asada, crunchy chips, fresh Baja battered fish.. And super quick service on top. If you live in this area you will never have to go to mission to get your Mexican fix:))
Loved it!
author: Anton K.

description:
So this isn't your typical authentic Mexican joint that you'd find out in the mission.  This is taco bar...on Fillmore.  Lol.  But don't be swayed by the chipotle like menu...

The food is pretty good...but the prices are a little high.  They offer agua frescas daily...whatever they have that is fresh.  I ordered a shrimp quesadilla...and it was freakin tasty.  Oh, and they aren't skimpy with the shrimp. 

Everything is made behind the counter...nothing is hidden.  I like seeing my food being made...just makes it taste that much better.
author: Jen W.

description: Fresh food lots of flavours. Quick and easy to get lunch and eat at the high bar or the two lower tables.
author: Lotta Y.

description: This place serves up some pretty good tacos of the "street" persuasion but at restaurant prices.   I only ordered un Veracruz taco.  It was first fish taco I have had in Northern California that made me wish I had ordered more.  At $4 a taco it a was a nice snack but nothing I would make a meal out of.  I would need at least 5 of those suckers to make a dent into an appetite like mine.
author: Melissa R.

description: How this place only has three stars is beyond me.  I love me a good fish taco and this place has the best!!! The best I tell you!!!  I love to cruise down Fillmore and get me a fish taco (or two) and some chips and guac.  And watermelon horchata.  SOOOOO GOOOOD
author: WC Gal Z.

description:
Wow...it has been a while since my last review. Here goes!

I've been to this place a number of times. My mom discovered it for the fam (not like Columbus or anything), so we swing by once every few weeks for some grub. When it's on the menu, the braised beef tongue tacos are the bomb...HELLA good. I love my organ meats and they do the tongue justice by allowing its natural flavors to hum, while the seasonings and accoutrements provide a nice kick. 

The quesadillas remind me of what I had as a kid when my mom would take us our for Mexican food; they are wrapped instead of flattened and cut into triangles. I suck at describing them, but I order mine with chicken and especial and it's solid. The taco salads are also very good. Crispy shell, fresh ingredients, filling, but not hella heavy in the belly.

All in all, this place will remain a go-to spot when I don't feel like trekking to the Mission.
author: Karim V.

description: Good neighborhood taco shop.  On the pricier side (although the place's rent is likely a key reason why), but their fish tacos, both grilled and fried options, are really tasty.  Their best item may be the chicken tortilla soup, which I can have any time of year.  Only item I haven't like are the chicken tacos... too bland for my taste. Still, I can eat here twice a month and be perfectly happy.
author: Samir N.

description: The Baja Pescado is a solid choice when your hungry and need to stop of a shopping break along Fillmore. Start it off with chips and guacamole, and share a margarita pitcher!
author: Regina D.

description:
TacoBar hits the spot. I haven't read through all of the reviews but it seems like most people review low because of the price. I think it's totally worth the price just for convenience -- particularly when I can't think of another solid median spot in lower pay heights. 

The servings are just enough to be full every time. AND I LOVE THE NACHOS!
author: Kaego R.

description: Disgusting.! worst burrito ever. carnitas tasted like potted meat and the cost was over $10 to add insult to injury. I will have to go to my old standby (the famous) La Taqueria on Mission near 25th for burrito redemption.
author: CJ C.

description: Decent food but way overpriced...3 tacos for 23 bucks?? They tried to charge us $3 extra for a tiny side of sour cream. Not coming back!
author: Ted P.

description: Stopped in on a busy Sunday at lunch time and managed to get a table outside!  I had the pescado tacos, very fresh tasting and delicious.  My friend had the chicken tacos which she said were very good.  The chips and salsa were ok, could've skipped them, but the agua frescas are a must!  Yum!
author: Laurie H.

description: So I think these are the best tacos I've had in sf. They chicken has a smokey mouthwatering flavor that explodes and consumes your taste buds. They were soft shell but came inside a crispy cheese shell. OMG sofa king scrumptious. They were kinds pricey (approx $21 for 3 and a watermelon juice) but worth it. The salsa & guac was fresh and flavorful. They will be seeing my face a lot now.
author: Court S.

description: Decent tacos and friendly service. The fish tacos weren't great. The lamb taco was tasty. I would go back if I was craving tacos and in the area.
author: Paul W.

description: Have no idea why this place gets 3 stars, by far the BEST breakfast burrito in San Francisco, and I"m an expert.  Everything else I've tried is fantastic too.
author: Chase N.

description:
I've wanted to go here for a long time but my special lady friend always said it's gross.  10 months later I got my way (first time yet.)
Don't let her know but she's right.  This place is gross.  But it's also over priced.
Will be my first and last visit.
It took 20 mins to get 5 tacos to go.  Crappy packaging.  Small.  Tortillas aren't even warmed.  I'm so sad to have gone here.
author: Chris F.

description:
Pretty great Lunch spot!

I've walked by this place quite a few times on my way to other lunch spots on Fillmore and I am so happy we went in today!

In the group we had the nachos, baja and veracruz tacos, a quesadilla, a churro and the blood orange aqua fresca.   Fish and the salsa were great, nachos and thick awesome chips =)!

Everything was really good the whole group walked away talking about how it would be our new lunch spot.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Hey, wanna pay 9$ for the blandest burrito you've ever had this side of the Mississippi? Then this is your place.

If you don't like any spice or flavor to your food, then this is the place for you.
I imagine that the owners thought "pale gringos will love our bland food and we can charge them out the ass for it!" when they opened this place up.

Save your money, go to the Mission or better yet, just make your own.

The two stars is for the decor of the place. It is clean and the cashier is always friendly as well.
author: Vince D.

description:
What do you get when you put an "authentic" (please note the quotation marks) taqueria with hipster-like decor on a swanky, yuppie corner of Fillmore Street?

A) Underwhelming Mexican food.
B) Overpriced Mexican food.
C) TacoBar.
D) All of the above.

For better tacos (note: I'm not necessarily saying more authentic), either head towards the Marina towards Tacolicious, or the other way on Fillmore towards the Mission.

(the answer is D)
author: Tori S.

description: I like the food here.  It is always fresh and not too greasy.  It's one of the better casual restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Mike L.

description:
FOOD: "Fresh Mex" / "Baja-style" Mexican-styled.  The ingredients are very fresh, and the flavors good but also very light.  The flavoring is not in the sauces or spices, but in the food items themselves.  Everything tastes just so darn fresh, and healthy-tasting.  (Don't expect to find greasy Mexican food here.)
All of the different tacos are great.  The burro is also good too - it's a good size, definitely smaller than a Chipotle burrito.

AMBIANCE:  Top 40's Latin music in the background.  A grab-and-go type of restaurant, but maybe enough seating if you're with a small group.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Just wanted to give everyone a heads up that this place is beer and wine ONLY. So when they advertise Margarita pitchers (26 dollars by the way) they are making it with wine NOT tequila. 

Food was good and quick. 

Service was friendly and they were able to refund us for our pitcher of margarita once we realized there was no tequila in it.
author: Josh W.

description:
This place can be good, as long as you follow a few rules.

1) Don't get the burritos. Both times they made me constipated, which is odd, considering the completely opposite reaction that Chipotle burritos invoke from my body. Also, they're pricey.

2) DO get the guacamole and chips. They're awesome.

3) DO get the kids quesadilla, extra crispy. It's well priced, and it's quite large.

This place is overpriced for most of their menu, and I often wish for the previous tenant, La Salsa, to return. However, if you want to not break the bank and enjoy some good food, split a kid's cheese quesadilla (extra crispy) and an order of chips and guac with a buddy. Not counting drinks, you can be out the door for under $10, and you won't feel bloated either.
author: Kevin H.

description: 6 shrimp tacos for 34 bucks with 2 drinks, say what? glad I didn't pay even though I wanted too but my bud said no. I couldn't believe the price! they tasted good & took care of my hunger, but at those prices I think not.
author: Henry K.

description:
I have in the past loved getting their guacamole and chips. Yum. Having a hankering, I stopped in today. I asked if they had a little bit of chopped onions that I could have and they did. For an extra charge. Really? I'm paying over $5 for a bag of ship and a small portion of guac and you want extra for 2 cents worth of onions? No thank you. You know how when guac has been exposed to air and it gets a darker green and has a sweetish, not-so-fresh taste? Well that's what I got. I tasted it to make sure that it was what I suspected  (i.e. not FRESH!) and yup, it was distinctly not so. I asked for another and when it came, it was better. Marginally so. Didn't think it worthwhile to ask again. Just won't risk it again. 
Guess I will be making my own from now on :(
author: Leslie C.

description:
This is a fun little place on Fillmore.  Service was pretty attentive, and it's a nice and relaxed atmosphere.  I had the tacos.  Carne asada taco was okay, and the Camaron taco is pretty good.

But the Pescado taco is AMAZING!  It's what keeps me coming back.  The fish is fried just right, so it's still moist and flaky with fried goodness all around.  It's good normal and especial, even though in the latter form the cheese on the outside can be ovewhelming.  Definitely get this if you come here.
author: Erwin V.

description: Sigh. I wanted this place to be good so badly, but it's probably the worst Mexican food I've ever had. My husband and I ordered chips with guac and salsa. The chips were teeth-breaking stale and the barely salted guacamole tasted like something you would get at a grocery store. The unsweetened hibiscus tea was so strong that it tasted like bad liquor. My vegetarian taco was a puny little thing featuring the bland guac, pinto beans and cold vegetables. My husband ordered a steak quesadilla and it was decent, but small. Even though it's enticingly convenient, avoid this place and go somewhere that actually knows what flavor is.
author: Amanda S.

description: Its ok if you want a burrito and you are in Lower Pac Heights. If you are used to burritos from the mission you will be disappointed. Not the best and kind of pricey.
author: Alex C.

description:
Taco Bar is right down the street from my house and has become my go-to dinner option when I do not feel like cooking.

I usually order the jicama salad and a side of corn on the cob.

The salad comes with jicama, grapefruit, roasted peanuts, and avocado. It is really light and makes for a refreshing meal.

The corn comes on the cob or in a cup and is served with crema fresca. 

I have also tried their carnitas nachos and quesadillas. They are both good, a little pricey, and I would suggest eating these items at the restaurant as they do not travel well.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Went there last night with five friends. I hadn't been  here in a couple of years. We an amazing time. The jicama salad never misses and the tacos were yummy just as I remembered them.  We were there for a couple of hours just drinking and munching on nachos. The staff was super friendly and checked up on us every so often for refills. Going back again soon!!
author: Amir A.

description: Rather pricey for tacos and such, but I keep going back for the green salsa, nachos, and fish tacos! Service can be slow, but that's fair since the place stays busy and everything is super fresh. Love to sit outside and people watch on this busy corner!
author: Sarah V.

description:
I'm addicted to their Baja Pescado tacos (tempura beer battered mahi mahi). I have to have them at least once a week. That with an order of tortillas chips and guacamole, and an Horchata drink...mmm.  
Maybe a little pricey compared to places in the Mission but it's the only place to get tacos in Pac Heights.
author: patricia F.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmm, this is by far the cutest taco place I've ever been to. With a bunch of eccentric yet delicious sounding tacos, how can you resist a place like this especially with such a cute name like "Taco Bar"?!

I came here at 10:30 AM for some food to cure the void in my stomach from a night's worth of drinking. I got the breakfast burrito with chorizo, scrambled eggs, rice, and beans and mm mm mm. TOTALLY hit the spot!

They have two salsa you can get: red or green. Green is limey-er and the red one is a bit spicier. The green one is my favorite. They also have horchata and watermelon juice for $2.80 and was pretty well made. One complaint? You have to BUY your own chips, they're not free :(

Why I'd come again? To try all their funky tacos. Oh, and have I mentioned how perfectly CYLINDRICAL their burritos are wrapped?! They're the gods of burrito rolling here.
author: Vicki L.

description:
This place is down the street from me, and I honestly don't know why I don't go there more often. I've gone a few times and with every visit the staff has been friendly, the place is extremely clean and well stocked, and the food is absolutely delicious (order the horchata!). 

I can't believe another reviewer is trying to compare the prices to a taco truck. Apples and oranges, guy. This is a walk-up and order *restaurant* with chairs and a cozy environment. You're not just paying for the food. 

In any case, I am going to work this place into my schedule more because it's mouth-watering delicious.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Sorry guys--given these guys multiple tries but they always mess up orders, or don't get your food ready when it should be.

Also just too expensive--four tacos for $17? And two of them are veggies. Insane.
author: Paul C.

description:
Pescado tacos were awesome. The Baja's fried with cabbage slaw and chile lime sauce and the Veracruz was grilled. Good fresh fish. The tacos come with two squeeze bottles full of red and green salsa, both flavorful and the verde with a bit of kick. 

Horchata was good, coconut flan with crispy coconut flakes was excellent. Fast, friendly service. Not cheap, but at just under $4 per pescado taco, pretty decent.

We just happened in here as we were walking down Fillmore, but it's good enough I'd hop off my bus ride home for a quick dinner.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Their tortilla soup is insane! I wanna buy gallons of it to freeze and always have on hand.

The rest of the food is amazing too...they do a taco salad in a baked shell that's probably the best deal in the house. Add steak and you're goo to go!
author: Jemma P.

description: I finally went here after walking past many times and had high hopes of satisfying my Mex food craving. While the service was fine the food unfortunately was not. I found the soap de tortillas, carne asado taco, Veracruz pescado taco, and horchata all to be rather bland. Better Mexican food can be found elsewhere.
author: Michael B.

description:
We ate here a couple of times..it was good but not amazing. 
It's one of the few taco places around the area with a nice inside with good amount of outside seating. 
The customer service is great here!!
author: Quinn S.

description: Hands down the best fish and shrimp tacos I have ever had in my life! The crunch on the deep fried fish is to die for with the mango salsa is perfect! The shrimp tacos taste amazing as well! We also saw somebody order a churro, out of curiosity we ordered it and it was no mistake! The churro came out and it was nice and warm after biting into it! We actually have Steven to thank a couple doors down at Travel Visa Pro since he recommended this place! Small little restaurant also, but with cute decor. On the tables they have espanol kiddie flash cards teaching you Spanish words. Only knock is its a bit pricey, but hey you are in the city right!?
author: Rosh E.

description:
With a plethora of Mexican options in San Francisco, going here when you are craving Mexican is a little silly. We go to share the nachos on the days when we don't want to travel far from the house. Trendy ambience. Quick service (because you are ordering yourself at the front) and outdoor seating options which is nice if you have furry babies. 

Go, just don't have the expectations they'll match the tacos and burritos you can get on everyone corner in the Mission.
author: Ashley W.

description:
They did such a great job catering our office lunch last week! Prompt, still hot and most important delicious! We ordered enough for the office and there was so much left over! The food was flavorful and not over cooked! The Carne Asada was tender, Carnitas nice a cripsy, and chicken not dry with great flavor! Beans and rice always go to the wayside but not these! Chips and guacamole were perfecto!!! We will def use them again. 

I also go in for lunch from time to time and order the taco salad! I swear the beef is so so so so good here! My favorite. 

Thanks Tacobar for all your hard work at making quality food.
author: Yumi D.

description: How is this place still open? They have no prices on their menu, most likely because their food is absurdly expensive for what it is. $4.25 for tiny tacos that really aren't all that good. Then on top of that you have to pay for chips. Stick to the mission.
author: J P.

description:
I really want to give Tacobar 4 or 5 stars but  paying 13 dollars for a burrito is a bit much. I understand this is located in pacific heights but I think there needs to be a realistic point of view on pricing at this specific restaurant. 

A quesadilla you can make at home will
Cost you about 10 dollars. It's a little pathetic.

It's also a shame because you have to drown your food In salsa for any good taste. 

The food is a 4 out of 10 and the chips aren't free.
author: Gabe G.

description: Waited 20 minutes just to get a Coconut Flan to go. Over priced Mexican food if you want REAL Mexican food thats worth it for the price go to El Farolito on Mission street
author: Lennie G.

description:
He Said:

I am a snob.  I grew up in San Diego so, of course, I know more about Mexican food than everybody.  This new-style interpretation that TacoBar does is pretty good.  The guac is a highlight here, even with slightly-less-than-perfect avocados.  The slaw was mostly flavorless, only providing crunch.  We opted for the shrimp taco special and the shrimp are big enough to make it hard to eat without a fork, but man, that breading is great.  The combined flavors are good and the salsas are excellent.  Overall a nice job with good prices in a neighborhood filled with high prices.

She Said:

We stopped by TacoBar as we wandered about San Francisco for the day. Our intent was to find some reasonably tasty food to get us through to dinner, and I was pleasantly surprised by what Taco Bar had to offer. I had a shrimp taco with guacamole, and the shrimp was wonderful. The breading was excellent, and the shrimp was cooked to perfection. Often with fried shrimp, you can't tell the difference between the breading and the shrimp, and this was definitely not the case here. Plus, the guacamole was pretty good. I would definitely be willing to stop again under similar circumstances.

She Said's Potty Points: This is a small space, so there's only one unisex bathroom. It was very clean, but although it was later in the day, there was still a wait to use the bathroom. I can't imagine what it's like during rush times. Because of the wait time, three out of five potty points!
author: He Said She Said ..

description: This place is terrible. I got the smallest quesadilla I've ever had in my life and it was almost $10. All it was was cheese and maybe 4 pieces of shrimp. As an SF native, you know good Mexican food when you see it. I know this is on Filmore street but it's outrageous for what you get. They even charge you for chips that have clearly been sitting out for hours under a heat lamp. I will not be returning here. If this was the mission you'd get salsa, guac and sour cream all for $10. I guess if you're from out of town you might not realize how shitty this place is compared to places like El farelito, el Buen sabor or taqueria Guadalajara. Go there instead. Save yourself some money.
author: Elenna D.

description:
Very consistent food!  Chicken burrito, shrimp taco---all good!
This taco stand sits on the corner of Fillmore & California, Lower Pac Heights area.
Remember to ask for "especial" on the tacos for a semi-hard, crusty cheese layer that wraps around your corn tortilla, and guac on top.  5 stars for the cleanest food and extra friendly/cheerful staff.  I think I eat here at least once a week.
author: H H.

description: So much better than la salsa when it was here! It's still not as authentic as the mission, but pretty good for pac heights. Staff is really nice and efficient.
author: Anne F.

description: We're those veggie tacos and jicama salad even real?? I normally stick to my usual when I order from the almighty Doordash, gotta say I am happy with my decision for tonight. Surprisingly you can mess up veggie tacos, fortunately these ones were solid and I enjoyed every minute. Same with the salad, super fresh and the jicama was perfectly crunchy. Definitely ordering from here again.
author: Nicole B.

description: It's funny how a super no frills quick as lightning cheap dump can make better tacos than this place. TacoBar's tacos are fine but they really leave no impression at all. For some reason TacoBar wants to really load the tacos up with a lot of ingredients, but what results is a taco that quickly falls apart into a sloppy mess. Either bigger and stronger tortillas or less filling.
author: Michael H.

description:
Was there yesterday and found the place lacking in just about everything.....except price.

Got a super burrito and it was filled with rice and beans very little chicken almost no sour cream or guacamole.  Virtually tasteless and waaaaayyyyy   OVERPRICED.

$28 for TWO BURRITOS!

Stay away.
author: Louis B.

description: Taco Bar is a little on the pricey side, but definitely good food.  I've only had the chicken tacos, chips and salsa, and lime pomegranate margarita, but I was impressed.  I also like the outdoor seating on Fillmore Street.  It gives you the opportunity to people watch during your meal.  But you can just as easily sit inside if the weather isn't so nice.
author: Stephanie V.

description: Cooks do not use gloves!!! The cook took nachos out of the oven and was transferring the food into a container. He used his hands, his entire palm and pushed the food into the container. Gross!
author: Cat B.

description:
The flavors are balanced and delicious. 

The tacos are kinda small. 

The chips with thick, warm, and excellent. 

The burrito was huge and well constructed. 

The price is rather high. 

The service is pretty disorganized and slow. 

The seating is very communal. 

The restaurant is going to get lost in the cornucopia of better options.
author: Susan C.

description:
Bit pricey for a taco joint, but it's fancy pants Pac Heights, so I guess, what do you expect?

Vegetarian tacos are good, and if you get the supreme taco, the soft tortila is wrapped in  crunchy, cooked/burnt cheese--kind of like a hard taco wrapped around a soft taco, except the hard taco is actually cheese.

I can't figure out if I think that's awesome or disgusting. I guess, kinda both. 

They have chilaquiles but only in the morning. Not as good as what I'm used to, but still good! Their cucumber lime agua fresca is also really good. Refreshing and crisp, like you'd hope. 

Definitely one of those solid standards.
author: Allison S.

description: Definitely below average. Please note that I came here for breakfast so I can't attest to their tacos. Very Inauthentic Mexican. I should've known better. Had the chorizo and eggs. 1st order had to be returned because the scrambled eggs were watery...very gross. Initial reaction when I mentioned that they were inedible wasn't very customer friendly. They remade my eggs...this time they didn't mix in the pico de gallo. Chorizo they use is not at all what would be used at an authentic mexican spot....and the prices DEFINITELY not reflective of their food. A plate of eggs and chorizo and an average tasting Carne asada burrito w 2 small horchatas almost $30. RIDICULOUS!! sorry fellow yelpers...I should've never doubted you. 2 stars just because the establishment was clean.
author: MC P.

description: Food was not that good, and was not a very good price for a burrito. I would not come back here again. It was probably the wettest burrito I have ever had. There's only one size for drinks and it's a water cup, also they charge for refills.
author: Isabella P.

description:
No prices on the wall menu - you have to ask for their paper takeout menu.  I'm not lazy but I rather look at the menu and know the price - the decision is a combo of both, isn't it.  Unless your bf takes you to a really fancy restaurant with pricing only on his (old school - does that happen?)

So after I find the prices, they seem high but I tried the burrito and quesadilla - both bland and I had to dowse it with hot sauce for taste.

What gave them an extra star (was going to be one) is their cool plant display - they have a cactus like spider plant hanging in a bottle...  check it out from the outside California Street side... worth the walk by.
author: Andrea K.

description:
My husband and I stumbled on Taco Bar on an afternoon stroll. Prices were reasonable, food was good - and we loved the especial option (avo and a cheesy crust around the tortilla). 

Granted, it's nothing fancy, but perfect if you want something easy and good!
author: Nicole D.

description: Ordered takeout and had my food ready when I got there. Ordered Horchata, Mango Fresca, 3 Carne Asada tacos, and 2 pescado tacos. Heard that the pescado was popular there so we had to give it a try and it was good! We were a little disappointed that they tacos were a bit on the smaller side since it was around $4 a taco. The Horchata and Mango Aqua Fresca was super refreshing though. Probably won't be back since it is on the pricer end, and nothing that Wows me. Spent $27 for a dinner for 3 so it wasn't bad.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Nice, modern, taqueria spot in the fillmore - tried it out since I parked pretty close by.

Walked in - got greeted right away, thats a plus!

Ordered: chicken quesadilla and one chicken taco.
Total: $14

I'm not sure how it came out to $14 since I didnt opt for a super taco nor a super quesadilla ... which is a bit steep for some mexican food.

Their flavors are there, well the chicken is that is - but I still cant justify what made the total to be that much - im not going to contest or argue. I thought the food was average, but next time I'll just wait and head to the mission for cheaper and tastier food. 

Thanks for the nice service though!
author: Kenny L.

description:
Like a taqueria version of Colibri or Tacolicious, TacoBar does more of a pan-mexican range of tacos than the Jalisco-style common in the Mission. The food is quality and authentic to what I found in Mexico City and other parts of central Mexico. 

We tried 5 tacos: the poblano and mushroom and the yucatan pork on the specials board, the grilled fish, grilled shrimp, and carnitas. All this was after some great chips (sprinkled with cotija) with three quality table salsas (red, green, and spicy charred red).

Most memorable was the vegetarian taco, with its great balance of herbs, pepper, and earthy mushroom flavors, rajas-style. I don't know why more places don't do stuff like this. For $3.75, it was enough bites to be a great deal for such flavor. 

The fish and yucatan pork tied for second. The fish was a decent sized piece covered in a rich tomato-y sauce, Veracruz-style, over a bed of cabbage. Crunch, sauce, silky fish, nice bites. 

The carnitas was the biggest portion. I was tempted to turn it into two tacos. And for $3.75, it was basically as much food as two $2 tacos at Mission places. The shrimp on the other hand was fairly tiny, so we didn't share that. But very very tasty nonetheless.

If you want great Mission tacos, go to Taqueria Vallarta. It's a totally different deal. 

But TacoBar is by far the cheapest option I've found in its natural competitive set, the pan-Mexican places like Tacolicious and Colibri.

**

Second trip in a week: Tried the special baja fish, which added guac and a crispy cheese layer outside the soft tortilla. The fish was delicious, super crispy and piping hot. Overall the package was unusual, tasty, and gimmicky, the kind of thing they should market more (it's rather hidden on the menu).

More importantly, this time we found the jicama and grapefruit salad. It was delicious and a huge portion. The chili-encrusted peanuts were a great foil. We'll go back just for this.
author: Sam P.

description: We used to go here a lot but no more.  Today I ordered to go and they charged me $13 for what appeared to be about a tablespoon of food and 6 small shrimp.  And it was not very good. Never again.  My wife was still starved after eating what was less than a kids portion.  Used to be a line but not today yet it still took them 1/2 hour to prepare this. Scratch this one off. Worse meal ever. Like a friend used to say "it was not good but at least it was really small."
author: Mike P.

description:
Decent AmeriMex style taco bar, but of course you pay for the location.  Expect $8-$10 for your tacos and burritos.

Everything I've tried here has been decent.  Well prepared and fresh.  Just nothing to write home about is all.

I think it's worth a visit to check it out, if in a pinch and in the neighborhood.  But I would not make some special side trip to see it.

The staff is also quite nice and remember you, if you're a frequent visitor.

I'll keep going because I'm in the area.
author: Patrick K.

description:
When I met TacoBar's "burros", the healthier no-rice version of the burrito, I thought: "Finally. a burrito I am free to love without shame." It's the burrito I am not embarrassed to Instagram about. Because it's filled with plump, juicy prawns, cabbage slaw, roasted ancho salsa, & jicama/mango salsa.

BUT THEN...I ruin my calorie count by ordering the coconut flan. 

But in my defense: 
Oh my GOD. If you tasted it, you would understand. I have "moments" with this flan. MOMENTS, I tell you.

Like...excuse me, but me and my flan need to be alone right now. Please go away. /shutsdoor

But it all balances out, because the rest of the menu is healthy and light. Burros come with carne asada, chicken, Mahi Mahi (tempura beer battered or grilled), or prawns.

They also serve sangrias and margaritas if you want to get happy hour started early....like at noon. Not that I do that, ever. 

I've been back three times in the past month so I think this is a sign of a pretty good relationship. If only I could stop whoring around with that flan. 
/probablynotgonnahappen
author: Mariela D.

description: Bad food and very bad service. Stopped for lunch, ended up spending $30 on two pina frescas and two burritos. Terrible food, bland and not worth the $$$. They messed up our order and didn't really follow what we wanted in our burritos and what we didn't, when we brought this up the lady at the cash register gave us major attitude.  Needless to say never going back there again.
author: alessandra d.

description:
I came to TacoBar on a Wednesday night after work because I didn't know where else to turn and was desperately hungry so thought, "why not?" 

I ordered a grilled pollo quesadilla with guacamole and sat down. Without knowing how much the total came to, I glanced at my receipt and did a double take; did this meal really cost me $11? "Oh well, the portions are probably large", I thought, "and ooh look, I'll probably be munching on those tortilla chips, too!"

Wrong. 

The waiter brought my food over to me, sat it down, and told me to enjoy. I wasn't expecting this kind of service but it was nice. Alas, my "quesadilla" had arrived. Having been to Mexico I was confused whether or not I ordered a burrito or a quesadilla as I'm pretty certain there is no distinguishing factor between the two here. My "quesadilla" was a burrito cut diagonally. Either way, I was hungry so I ate.

Now, here's the kicker: portion size. People say the portions are too small or they're too large, well, here's the scoop: if you're looking for a mission style, filled to the brim, explosively large quesadilla/burrito thing then this is NOT your place. The portion is sized where you can finish your meal, go on a stroll for an ice cream, and be perfectly satisfied. The quesadilla thing itself was very tasty and I enjoyed it very much.   

Why I'm knocking off two stars? 

Price- I know you guys comment on people's reviews saying, "We are sorry, we provide quality food, and that, obviously adds up to the cost..." blah blah blah, but would it kill you to provide chips and salsa with burritos, quesadillas, and tacos? Honestly, you are already making a ton of money off the food, will it really break your business to add a little something else (especially something as cheap as tortilla chips)? Why does guacamole have to cost so much and why can't that just be a part of the cost, too?

TacoBar is a poor alternative to other places in San Francisco because of it's pricing and food quantity. I'd suggest checking out places in the mission if you're looking for a more authentic experience (including quality, pricing, and atmosphere). I would say TacoBar is my favorite mexican restaurant on this side of town (which really doesn't say much, to be honest) because there isn't really much competition.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Feeling a bit restless on a Sunday morning Dude and I decided to take a stroll through The Fillmore. We started to get the brunchie munchies and chilaquiles accompanied by a cold Pacifico sounded like a fabulous idea.

We decided to share the large plate of chilaquiles so that I'd have room for a second Pacifico. The portions were decent, but the chilaquiles were nothing to rave about. Thankfully a Pacifico came to the rescue and took the taste out of my mouth. Literally.
author: Bomb D.

description:
starving so got a single shrimp taco to go...

for $4.50 it contained 2 small prawns with one still having it's tail-on and not deveined. know what the vein of a shrimp is? ewww, super gross! oh and the taco included some slaw that had def seen better days.

add in the register guy was rude and didn't give a damn about the non-blonde female customers (huge diff in attitude), not a pleasant quick stop.
author: Missy D.

description:
I thought this was really good, I don't know what all the fuss is about. The price does suck, but it is Pac Heights, so what do you expect. It's almost $4 for a taco, but a really good taco. Vegetarian taco (flour  torilla wrapped in a fried cheese crisp tortilla, with beans, salsa, lettuce, cheese avacado) and fish taco (fried/grilled, good mayonnaise-y sauce, cabbage) were awesome. 

Quesadilla was meh and my boyfriend said his steak taco wasn't good. But beans and rice here are good, and ingredients are fresh. Sangria was good. Cute atmosphere. I'd go again.
author: Ruby L.

description: Great tacos and atmosphere! Margaritas aren't the best I've ever had, but definitely did the trick
author: Katie L.

description:
Visted TacoBar on a whim.  Craving some awesome tacos, I strolled into the tiny spot and checked out the menu.  First observation was that there were no prices.  You know the old saying, "if you have to ask..."  I stepped up thinking how bad could it be.  I ordered a plate of three tacos and a Mexicoke.  
The tacos were just OK.  I mean they were good but not awesome.  The bad part was that they were tiny for the price.  I ate three and left hungry.  For the price I paid, I could've done much better in the area.
I was hoping to find a new surprise but this place was just OK.
Street parking can be tough on nearby streets
author: Pablo R.

description: I was offered a menu after walking into the establishment.  That was very nice considering there was a slight line, and I looked like I clearly hadn't been there before. The cashier was nice and offered me options on what I ordered. I did find it strange, for a Mexican restaurant, they didn't offer chips and salsa for free. But hey, it's San Francisco. As far as food goes, it's run of the mill. Nothing spectacular, but definitely worth trying if you're in the area and are in the mood for Mexican food. The staff is attentive and even seem to cater to and care for the nearby "neighbors". If you've been to SF, you know what I mean. Good people, good food. Check them out.
author: W E.

description: Average....my girlfriend and I were stopping to get cupcakes next door but decided to stop in here to try out the tacos. The atmosphere is pretty great with some interesting decorations and Spanish learning cards on the table. The food itself though was average we had the vera Cruz taco (grilled fish) and shrimp taco. The fish and shrimp were good but the salsa was not that great. I'm giving it 3 out of 5 because I feel I may be a tough critic with tacos. It was a little over priced as it was about 15 bucks for 2 tacos and a small horchata....but then again it is on filmore street.
author: Jose E.

description:
Roomie: Where did you and your bro go to eat?
Me: TacoBar.
Roomie: And how were your tacos?
Me: TINY.
Roomie: And really expensive?
Me: YES! Ugh, I had to eat a luna bar after. But they were good. 

Next time I'm going to order like, 10 tacos, if there is a next time... which isn't likely.
author: Emily D.

description: $10 carne asada burrito.  The meat had the texture of being stewed or boiled, not grilled, and the rice and beans were watery.  No flavor to it.  Wish I had my $10 back...
author: L W.

description:
Why settle for a paucity of choices, bland Cali-Mex food, and high prices at Tacobar when there are so many better burrito joints in The City?

Located at the corner of California and Fillmore in a former Una Mas space, Tacobar has the right idea:  use local, organic ingredients, line caught fish, and all natural beef to try to make upscale Latin fare.  As always, the down fall is the execution.

Despite the black Angus beef, the carne asada burrito ($7.75) was utterly flavorless.  Not spicy, not tasty, not even that good.  To top it off, there were no options for a whole wheat tortilla, black beans, or extra spicy picante sauce were listed on the printed menu or the menu board, just a regular flour tortilla, pinto beans, and Americanized, flavorless pico de gallo.  The tacos ($3.45 for carne asada, pollo, or carnitas and $3.75 for fish) are small, small, small, and just as flavorless.  No complimentary basket of chips was offered.

In addition to the soulless entrées, the two salsas offered were amateur, at best.  The red, chipotle-based sauce was too smoky, and the green, tomatillo-based sauce lacked fire.  There were not even any branded sauces (Tapatio, Cholula, or even the old standby Tabasco) available to make up for the poor quality housemade sauces and increase the heat.

Service was friendly and the cashier moved people through the line quickly.  The line cooks were quick, and food was delivered promptly.

In this city full of excellent Mexican establishment, one could (and should) expect more.  With its high prices and top-notch ingredients, Tacobar just doesn't deliver.
author: CJ G.

description: Seconding Isabella's review. Not that good and a bit pricey for a burrito over $10. Only had the Baja Pescado but too much cabbage and not a fan of either of their salsas. Good service though. I'd recommend going somewhere else unless you're dying for Mexican and on filmore
author: Tristan S.

description:
Overpriced tacos. Chips are not free. Cheese on top of chips are not free. Small portions. Hostess doesn't disclose that EVERY addition costs money until you get the bill.

After having Good tacos...this place is definitely a one star for the price/quality ratio.
author: Christopher K.

description: The staff here were so helpful finding options for me; I have an onion and garlic allergy. The cheese quesadilla was delicious, cheesy, and perfectly browned. The pricing is good and the quesadilla was presented in a pleasing way in a rectangular dish. More vegetarian options would be nice. Thank you!
author: Sharman C.

description:
I paid $24.50 for three small tacos and a burrito that had only steak, rice and beans.  I haven't felt this ripped off since I had my laptop stolen from my car.

The tacos start at $3.85 and Burritos start at over $8.00.  You can do way better at a local taco truck.

The food tastes "ok", but you get very very little for the amount you have to pay.

I definitely will not be returning.  SF has way too many more options for Mexican cuisine than to go to taco bar a second time.
author: Edmond S.

description:
Incredibly epic tacos here. Sure, you pay a bit more, but these babies are seriously the best tacos I've had north of Mexico.
It's funny reading peoples opinion on the cabbage/slaw in the tacos, etc. People: That's the way they do it in Mexico, and this IS Mexican food thank the lord. If your not happy, go to anyone of the quasi-Mexican-Americanized places that infest the rest of the city and enjoy your iceberg lettuce and cheese and subsequent waistline.
Real friendly staff. I suggest the baja style and the (if they have it that day) the pulled-pork Yucatan style taco. I'll be back.
PS. Avoid the chips, they are too good.
author: Brian J.

description:
This place was so incredibly overpriced for BOTH the quality AND quantity of food served. I am embarrassed for them. I felt like a fool handing over my credit card. 

Oh, Fillmore, you crack me up.
author: Joel G.

description: Wayyy overpriced!!! Ordered takeout no forks napkins no chips salsa $$30 for taco and 2 nachos!!!
author: Oliver W.

description:
Try the Quesadilla Especial!!  It's off the charts good.  

Every time I leave my husband to fend for himself for dinner, he was always going to TacoBar and getting a Chicken Quesadilla Especial.  One day, we decide to share one and it was a complete food orgasm.  It's shaped like a burrito, perfectly grilled, and every bite is a taste of deliciousness.  My mouth is watering as we speak.  We also share the carne asada burrito especial which is tasty too.  I've tried the tacos here and they were ok, small and average tasting.  But, the Quesadilla Especial is a must!
author: Shelly W.

description: Food was very good. I just wish they'd post their prices cause I feel like the prices change.  But still excellent food.
author: T B.

description:
The place is cute and it's inviting, but I'm not so sure about the food. While this is called the Taco Bar, I should have ordered some tacos, but instead, I had me a Carne Asada Quesadila.  It's not how I expected.  The tortila itself was flaky and it wraps the meat tightly.  There wasn't enough cheese and it tasted bland.  Even with the added salsa wasn't good enough.  

I think I'll pass.
author: Meshell C.

description:
This place is great... I'm not sure if its just what I ordered, but the fried fish taco was some of the best I've had, and while the carne asada taco flavors were not my personal favorite (If I'm being honest, I like my carne asada greasy and rich, not light and fresh... ), it was still delicious. They overstuff these tacos, so if you're a relatively smallish portion eater, 2 tacos are more than enough for a meal. I can't recommend the fried fish tacos enough, the sauce was great, the batter and fry perfect, the fish juicy and well flavored (you can tell they use good fish).

And, the staff is really nice. Like really nice. Like my debit card was locked and she took what cash I had and told me not to worry about it. 

I will definitely be going back!
author: Jess F.

description:
(See pics)

Well, I don't know about the tacos other than watching my friend having it. I did have a coconut flan which was just okay. For some reasons Fillmore cafes tend to be crayon colourful.

The nachos had the salsa on top of them, which we found a bit unusual as the chips got soggy a bit quickly before we can finish the whole basket.
author: T L.

description: This place was cute- I couldn't help thinking of how fun and festive the environment was.  The line was slow when we got there- I was hoping that this meant it was just good.  The menu proved to be difficult for my Paleo diet and I ordered a taco salad sans shell instead. The salad was decent- fresh chicken and guacamole. My friend had 2 of the fish tacos and enjoyed them.  The staff was kind and tried to get everyone their orders quickly.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Wonderful San Francisco gem serving great inexpensive Mexican food in a neighborhood you wouldn't expect: Pacific Heights!  One of the best parts is that this place hasn't yet been discovered by the masses, so food can be obtained without horrendous lines and inexorable waiting times like so many other SF spots.  You may have to wait for an outside table on a sunny day, however.

We recommend the camaron taco, the carne asada burrito (I swear this baby weighs about 2 lbs!), and the chips, salsa, and guacamole.  Keep your eye on the daily specials, however, as those can be equally delicious (cow tongue anyone?).  Two tacos with some shared chips is plenty of food for one person.  The camaron taco is served with cabbage instead of beans (the cabbage isn't smothered in mayo, thankfully), so it is a nice healthy alternative.  

Ingredients claim to be local/free-range/organic and all that great stuff.  You will not be disappointed eating here, whether dining in the restaurant or (better yet if you live nearby) getting take out.  

In response to the posters who complain that the chips and salsa are not free, we have found that many "authentic" taquerias in the Mission also charge for chips and salsa.  TacoBar's chips are especially delicious and worth the few extra bucks, plus paying extra seems pretty standard for SF (ever notice how Thai/Burmese places in the City charge you for rice?).

We eat here about once per week because it never disappoints and prices are extremely reasonable for Pacific Heights and not unreasonable for any part of the City.
author: Wolfgang C.

description:
I'm confused at why this place gets so much business. It's really just "Meh". The food is just aiiigh, and the prices are redic. I had a burrito, and my friend had tacos. Almost $4 for a taco is insane! 

I think it gets business because it's the only Mexican food spot in the area, and this is Pacific Heights. If it were located in the Mission or Fruitvale, forget about it.

I think overall the Mexican food in the East Bay is waay better than in SF, EXCEPT for Pancho Villa! That spot is number one!
author: Melissa B.

description:
The employees are great and the place is clean and well lit.  There's nothing wrong with the service.

But, as many reviewers have posted, the food is both bland and expensive.  I came here with my two little kids (5 and 2) and ordered from the kiddie menu, and there are NO PRICES listed on the menu.  Not for anything.  But I figured the kiddie burritos (beans/cheese/rice) wouldn't be too expensive.  But our total came to almost $30 for two tacos, two kids burritos, and chips and salsa (I didn't get guacamole or drinks to save money).  Aren't chips and salsa complimentary?  We did get 3 tap waters, so maybe we were charged for them?  I had was holding $20 in my hand and expected to get some change!  These are not taqueria prices.
Either way, the food wasn't bad, it just had no real spice to it.  The carne asada taco was OK, but I'm still not sure why everything was so expensive.  It tasted very mild and Americanized. The kids burritos weren't bad, but neither of my kids finished their food, so if we do return I'm going to order one burrito and cut it in two.  
If you are dying for Mexican and in Pac Heights, this may be your only option, but next time I'm going to insist on asking the prices before I order and make sure I get the food extra picante.
author: Alexander T.

description:
You are sadly mistaken if you walk into this joint expecting mission style burritos or tacos. This place is the organic, higher priced, fancier version. If you are willing to try out their new specials (duck, wild mushroom etc.) and you have a few extra dollars in your wallet, then this is a place to check out. If you are looking for the standard fare, quick meal, you probably won't be too satisfied with this place. 
Service was friendly, food was decent but small portions, chips and salsa are not free (although they'll ask you like they are.)
author: Naomi K.

description: I only ever order one thing when I come here, so I can't speak for the rest of the menu, but for the item I DO know - the Baja Pescado Tacos - they are, quite simply, Excellent. Great fish, delicately fried, nice toppings... (OK, perhaps their tortillas are a bit small for the piece of fish they put on them, which results in them being a bit unmanageable to eat, but I appreciate that they're corn instead of flour). I'd put these against the ones at Woodhouse Fish Company any day. In fact, I think I like them BETTER. Not that Woodhouse's are BAD. They're lovely, in fact. These are just a tad more enjoyable to me. The only other thing I wish is that the seating area weren't so fast-food like. I'd love some dimmer lighting, more comfortable seating, a few more drink options. I rarely feel inclined to sit down & have my meal here. Instead, I always take my order to go. Overall, though, I'm happy to have TacoBar in my neighborhood. It's a place I visit frequently. :-)
author: Eric H.

description: Ordered a taco salad yummy wish I had more meat inside it though. Nice friendly staff And environment. I do look forward to going back soon. You can watch the cook make your meal also .
author: Val J.

description: Mediocre Mexican food that has probably survived this long only because it's the only Mexican food place within a large radius.
author: Kevin M.

description: Good food, good salsa. Love how they marinate the chicken. However, I had a super chicken burrito with an extra side of guacamole and it was $15.00. Pacific heights prices. not a place I'd frequently visit due to the pricey-ness but overall the food is very good.
author: Kay C.

description:
Move over Nick's Crispy Tacos and Tacolicious... there is new kid on the block! 

Taco Bar, located in the former La Salsa space on the corner of Fillmore and California, is brought to you by a Nick's Crispy Tacos alum, who sought to bring a slice of Mexican deliciousness to Pac Heights. 

Unfortunately, the food is just okay (burritos, quesadillas, tacos), and at $5 per taco, the prices are a bit steep. My lunch of 2 tacos and a drink was $14. The batter on the fish in my fish taco was thick and slightly undercooked and the carne asada taco was bland. I am hopeful that because today is opening day, the kinks will be worked out in time. Taco Bar does get bonus points for its commitment to use local organic ingredients whenever possible, such as line caught fresh fish, free range chicken and all natural Angus beef and pork.

Oh, and did I mention the dessert menu includes coconut flan and tequila ice cream? Yes, please!
author: Alice W.

description:
WOOF.  Talk about inconsistent and underwhelming.

The food is average at best and the prices are expensive for what you get.

Its only saving grace is its grilled corn when they actually serve it (it's a special).  I ordered it one time and it actually made me want to go back, so I did.  Second time around, I ordered it and 10 minutes later, they tell me they don't have it, and offered a substitute.....corn in a cup with supposedly the same flavor on it.  The manager actually said it's better.

FAIL.

It tasted like canned del monte corn with all the watered down juice still in it.

I really wanted to like the place b/c Lower Pac Heights needs good Mexican...but seriously....

WOOF
author: Kyle W.

description:
Wandering through the Fillmore Street area last Saturday, my companion and I were looking for a little nibble around lunchtime. We came across TacoBar and it was exactly what we needed. We ordered a few tacos and two pomegranate lime margaritas. we headed out to one of the outdoor tables to wait for our food. moments later, our drinks arrived. they hit the spot...tart, tangy, just enough alcohol -- perfect for a sunny day. 

our tacos arrived shortly thereafter and they were excellent. living in phoenix, i eat a lot of street tacos and these ranked way up there. 

carne asada -- beef chunks with pinto beans and a bit of cheese. smoky, meaty and quite satisfying. 

veracruz style fish tacos -- chunks of fish (not breaded) with cabbage and pico. we added some tomatillo salsa to make them extra special.

wish we would have ordered more! :)
author: Barb H.

description:
WHO... me + 1 

WHAT... Baja/Fresh Mex meets contemporary design... great flavors & spices. Was 
               def. on my list of spots to try, but not sure if I had a craving for Mexican ... if 
               this spot would pop into my mind first.

               I had the Fresh Lime Agave Margarita for starters followed by the grilled    
                mahi mahi & shrimp tacos. Margarita was just alright... and my fav of the two 
                tacos was the shrimp. 

WHEN... Thursday afternoon - not too long of a wait.

WHERE...Limited seating, counter seating, outside seating  & communal tables. After 
                  waiting for a spot to open up, sat at the counter.
author: Teena Marie T.

description:
I'm a big fan of Mexican food so I was looking forward to trying TacoBar.  The menu looked really good with a variety of tempting items offered.  I ordered the Veracruz Pescado and carnitas tacos with a hibiscus tea agua fresca.  

The food was good, but I wish that there was more of it.  Each taco was the size of a street taco.  Perhaps a side of chips with each order would have helped.  I dropped in after a hard workout so maybe my opinion was influenced by the fact that I was super hungry.  

Looking around I liked that the owner was socially responsible and wanted to serve fresh, tasty, well made food at somewhat reasonable prices.  I'm all for that and like to support local businesses, but the only downside is that the portions are really on the small side.  Oddly enough, a side order of chips is pretty generous and is a bargain for the price.
 
Would I go back?  Yes I'd give TacoBar another try, but I'll probably order a burrito or quesadilla next time.
author: Melissa L.

description: I don't care what the haters say, I really like this place: it's not 'autentico', perhaps, and very much not hip, but the fish tacos are better than most joints in the city, the chips are fresh, and it's kid-friendly (working high chairs, reasonably fast service). All in all, I like it.
author: sellMyFing n.

description:
Walking through the neighborhood, searching for the lucky establishment where we would dine for the evening and in the distance...the bf and I see TacoBar. SOLD! 

This is how it goes. Check over the menu...order at the register, then BAM (minutes later you have your food. Crazy fast! There are several tables inside, as well as a table bistro table and a few 2 tops outside. 

Service was solid. From the moment we walked through the door...everyone was very friendly and again the food came out very fast. 

What we ordered...
*Guacamole - smooth and delicious. Chips are thick and very good. They will sprinkle Cotija cheese on them too if you would like. 
*I went with the Avocado Ensalada Cesar (Romaine, w/Avocado dressing, Cotija Cheese, Cilantro & Totopos Croutons). You can add chicken, steak or shrimp for a fee. I was pretty happy with the flavors and the price (less than $10) was perfect for the portion size. 
*The bf went with 3 tacos - 2 steak and 1 brisket (which was on special and came with horseradish cream sauce). He loved the flavors, but felt that they were a tad pricey for what they were. He added guac to the tacos ad they ended up being around $5/each. 
*Corn tortillas - just eh, which upset me because I was hoping they would have some killer tortillas. Oh well. 
*Lime Margarita - just ok. A bit strong on the lime and not so much on the tequila. 

Overall...tasty food, great service and a fun atmosphere. I highly suggest you give them a try!
author: Dru M.

description:
We are vegetarian and we always order the Vege tacos. 

They are delicious. Always consistently good. They are made with a crunchy cheese shell with a soft taco shell inside. They use fresh vegetables, beans, salsa and always plenty of guac..

Also both their salsas, red and green, are good.
author: Mayur K.

description: This is, in essence, a chipotle like taqueria. I don't go here when I want a mission style burrito the size of my head with an incredible salsa bar selection for 7 dollars. For that, I go to the mission. I go here when I'm in the area and want Mexican tasting food with fresh and perhaps locally sourced ingredients (for a price). The food tastes good and I'm not questioning whether the meat is cow, dog or something worse. Yes, it is a gringa, expensive taqueria, but I'm a bit confused about what people expect given the neighborhood and clientele they are catering to. Go for the Baja fish tacos especial and you won't be disappointed.
author: Amy M.

description: I swear this is the best quesadilla in SF. Carne Asada with sour cream and quac with some of their red hot sauce.. Life changing.
author: Dan L.

description:
I went for dinner and got 3 tacos, all fish-themed:

The mahi-mahi taco was bland and largely tasted of dry corn tortilla

The shrimp taco was spicier and tastier.  The shrimp themselves were nicely seasoned and the mango salsa was great.

The fried fish taco was the most substantial and tasty. The fish had nice crispy batter outside and wasn't overcooked inside. Spicy salsa and lime-sour cream sauce sealed the deal.

The three tacos was plenty of food for dinner, and the price for just the tacos was reasonable.

I also ordered a glass of sangria, which was tasty, but cost too much for the small glass.
author: Marty F.

description:
Alright, so initially I had a bit of a beef with this place. Buuut, It all boiled down to a bit of a Yelp-Review misinterpretation...I am not really one to hold a grudge, so I decided to check this place out for lunch.

I'm glad I did. It's a solid Mexican place. 

I ordered the Fish Burrito and was way impressed by how flavorful and tender the fish was. Perfectly seasoned and cooked. That said- I will say that the rest of the burrito (coleslaw etc) was fairly bland. I even opted to pay the extra bit to have sour cream & guac added. Still a bit bland (i like things spicy & saucy). Fortunately, there's house-made salsa on every table. 

Prices are a bit steep... I paid $10 for my burrito. And that doesn't even come with a side of rice or anything. Ouch. However, I will forgive them because at the end of the day- Organic, Local Ingredients are going to cost a bit more than the alternative and the have to make their costs up somehow. 

The digs look great, too. Lots of great natural light. Ample sitting space. Awesome decore finishing touches. Very Mexico-Chic. They even have a couple tables outside on the sidewalk, which would be nice on a hot day.  The staff was VERY nice and friendly, and my food came out as ordered and quickly. Which was surprising considering today was their FIRST day in business. Well done- kudos!

Apparently they are committed "when possible" to using organic, local ingredients. I love that and applaud the effort. Definitely wish more businesses would do the same. 

Additionally, they also use "Piedmontese" beef.. which initially impressed me...  Piedmontese Beef, in short, is fancy, organic & freerange cows from Italy. (Now, perhaps there are herds of these cows locally... But I assume they are importing this beef from Italy.) So, wouldn't make more sense to buy organic, free-range LOCAL beef and save yourself the huge carbon footprint? I realize that this Piedmontese Beef is meant to impress us ("oooh! fancy beef from ITALY!) , and I don't mean to knit-pick... But yeah, I wish they'd go local with that one. 

Regardless, this is a great place and I'd definitely go again. It's nice to have a Mexican joint on Fillmore again.
author: Tamara B.

description: This place has dramatically changed since they first opened. Very fresh, very tasty. I'm a convert!
author: Robynne W.

description:
The food is good and really tasty, if I'm craving some tacos then this is one of my first choices.

But the negatives are that the place is small, hot, and slightly over priced.  But after seeing what rents along Fillmore are I guess shelling out an extra dollar is the price you pay for a Mexican joint to be close by.
author: Bobby L.

description: Taco Bar is Cali-fresh, often organic top quality ingredients. They just don't brag about it a ton. I keep going back for the Camaron Burro: ancho marinated grilled shrimp with cabbage slaw and mango salsa. A truly lighter, healthier, tasty take on a burrito.  Most worthy for a small taqueria.
author: Jake Z.

description:
Dependable food, good service, very friendly staff
The prices are not cheap but understandable given location.
I would definitely recommend
author: SF H.

description: This is our go-to place. It is never too crowded so we are able to sit outside on the weekend. The Quesadilla Camaron is my favorite. You cannot go wrong at Taco Bar. We crave it constantly.
author: Fallon R.

description:
Had TacoBar catered for my pre wedding party. The staff was extremely friendly and professional from the first phone call.
I was reassured that the amount of food was going to be plenty for my guests and we had leftovers. My guests raved about the food and I received a personalized call the next day from the owner to make sure everything went well (and a congrats).
author: Nicole O.

description:
This is not a mission Taco bar. It may cost more than your average Mexican joint but to be honest it tastes much better. I absolutely don't agree with those who think authentic mean a "real" tacoria has to be a sloppy dump. The food here is as good as any on Fillmore. 

I took one star because I do wish the portions were a little larger but I guess the rent is to high to hook it up.
author: Anthony M.

description:
I have not had the chance to check out the lovely array of restaurants and bars on the Fillmore St. Luckily, my boyfriend and I were entertaining his cousin and wife who were staying in the Japantown. Even after the rain, the four of us walked further and further seeing, stopping, and contemplating what to fill our stomachs with. So when we see a sign that has the words "taco" and "bar" in its name. We. Were. Sold. 

My boyfriend and I split the nachos con queso with carnitas and a very tasty fish taco. Don't know which one he ordered, but nevertheless both dishes were mouthwatering and yummy to le tummy. Even our visitors were gushing about TacoBar's burritos all weekend. I particularly relished in their watermelon juice. I see that there are more in SF, must eat, enjoy and repeat.
author: Jamie L.

description:
The food is meh. It's neither the comfort Tex-mex nor amazing Mexican. It seems like half the food is prepackaged and then microwaved.

We started with chips and salsa where the chips are thick but sadly sort of cold. The salsa is pico de gallo that is simple bland. Some heat or salt would make it better. Then for the meal I had a vegi taco that had good guacamole on it which is all I can compliment on. My SO had the vegi torta that was bland too.
author: Seamus L.

description: So puzzled why this doesn't have higher reviews. Live down the street and have frequented this place often. Every time quick great service and awesome burritos. Hands down one of my favorite spots around. Can't go wrong
author: Mark W.

description: I'm here at least once a week and I always get their chicken taco salad. It's become a regular craving. I could do without the whole wheat shell, but everything else is amazing. Especially their chips and guac! A little pricey (what isn't on Fillmore) but delicious!
author: Jessica E.

description: So, I've learned through trial and error what to order at TacoBar - the chicken burrito is hearty and flavorful and the chips are also delicious, they are fresh and I really like TacoBar's guac.  I found the fish tacos to be skimpy and other items mediocre.
author: Liz Y.

description:
I have eaten at TacoBar twice now and had a fantastic experience both times.  
-Cute atmosphere with indoor and outdoor seating
-Friendly and helpful staff
-Delicious quesadillas and burritos
-Love the salsas
author: Christy L.

description:
I'm surprised by the mediocre reviews of this place.  I totally dig it.  I know that you can get awesome burritos for dirt cheap in the Mission, but this place is not in the Mission.  It's in Pacific Heights.  So expecting Mission prices is just plain silly.  

For $25 my boyfriend and I got two delicious burritos, a beer and chips, which is a pretty damn reasonable price for dinner for two, if you ask me.  Aside from the delectable food, the service was fantastic.  They were extremely friendly as I blundered my way through the order (ordering  dinner when your head is full of cold medicine is not always the most coherent thing to do), and to top it all off, they insisted on making me a new burrito when I realized too late that I had forgotten to ask them to make mine without rice.  The manager (owner?) told me that he wanted me to enjoy my meal, so he would make me a new burrito for free.  

I will definitely be going back...and enjoying every bite.
author: Jessica H.

description: Short rib tacos with horseradish was wonderful. Esquite  yum, corn and lime and spice delicious!
author: Leigh S.

description:
Deeeeeelicious!

Baja taco rules.  Really yummy, fresh tasting everything.

Clean, crisp atmosphere with sweet staff.

I soooooo wished they delivered, but certainly don't mind since it's such a great little spot.
author: Alexis M.

description: I have had a big change of heart about Taco Bar. I still find the prices higher than average for Fillmore, but my opinion of the food, and the restaurant overall, has turned around. I have been getting the tacos for awhile now, but today I tried the tortilla soup, and I liked it so much that I had to write a new review immediately. It was perfect. Service is friendly, there's a nice mix of chairs and stools so you can sit or stand however you feel comfortable, and the cucumber aguas fresca is delicious. Thank you, Taco Bar, for changing my mind!
author: Molly P.

description:
Overall the food is really tasty and fresh. A bit pricey, but worth the coin considering the organic, free range animals and veggies.

My favorites are the shrimp burrito (very filling and by far one of the best shrimp burritos I've had) and quesadillas.

The veggie burritos were great until the replaced the mushroom with potatoes, which belongs only in a breakfast burrito if you ask me.
author: Jenaynay W.

description:
After some serious shopping, we were looking to recharge...Maybe it was the sign outside the door that promised margaritas, or the daily special of a Duck confit taco...But Tacobar was the highlight our eating adventures this weekend.

We ordered a kid's burrito, the mahi mahi taco, the shrimp taco, the carne asadas taco, the fried fish taco, and of course the duck confit taco, add to that a side of chips, salsa and guacamole...And of course, margaritas! 

The guacamole was chunky which is the best kind, and when we asked for their "hot salsa", a red bottle was brought to the table with this wonderfully hot green salsa...Out of this world. 

I tried the duck confit taco first, and while the salsa overpowered the duck confit, I have to give Tacobar points for trying something different...Put a little less salsa, and play up the mango aspect of it, and tone down the citrus...and you may have a winner. The fish and shrimp tacos were delicious, and i heard no complaints about the carnitas from my boyfriend. The margaritas were partly frozen, and we prefer ours on the rocks. So we asked the manager if we could have the next ones on the rocks, and lo and behold, he came back with margaritas sans ice - and when we asked for another round, they also came out sans ice...Now that is customer service.

The tortas, the quesadillas, and the future specials are all on the list for our next visit. And if you are walking down Fillmore, make the stop...you won't regret it.
author: Laurence B.

description:
TacoBar is absolutely the white man's taco eatery...

Which is true, look where its located, in the heart of a gentrified Fillmore and California. I don't think there is nothing authentic about TacoBar, it resembles more of a Chipotle or a Taco Bell then a taqueria in the Mission, to add to the feel that its a white man's taco eatery, its expensive. Almost 9 quid for a quesadilla. There are a couple of things i appreciate about this place. Outside seating and fresh ingrediants, other then that, Mexican authenticity such as radish, lime, home made recipe for salsa, and grilled jalapeños are absent.
author: Rio A.

description: Nice stop in for a quick and casual lunch. Friendly service.
author: Vicki L.

description: Ask and you shall receive! Thank you Jack for listening to your customers and coming through on your promises.
