Tacobar is offering a wider variety of weekly specials now - including tacos w/ garlic mushrooms and leeks, which is probably the best thing I've  had here to date! Kudos to Jack and to Tacobar.
author: Gev M.

description: I love this place. Everytime I'm here I talk about how I'm going to write a positive yelp review, but I forget. I grew up in the Bay, but I am currently living in NYC/Brooklyn. I have not had anything as good there as I have here. Breakfast burrito, carnitas, shrimp. All amazing. I highly recommend this place.
author: Joshy P.

description:
Don't be surprised to spend a few more dollars here than your typical taco shop. This is the Pacific Heights, where the cost of food highly correlates with the standard of living.  Despite a tight budget, I was craving tacos one night and this was the closest place I could get to at the time.

I ordered baja fish tacos and added the Tacobar Especial (cheese and guac) for $1.25. Boy, was I in for a nice surprise. The fish tacos were the right amount of crunchiness, the sauce was flavorful, and there was an abundant amount of guac layered on top.  It did cost me $11 for two tiny tacos,  but nonetheless was a quite satisfying amount spent.
author: Denise W.

description: Decent American-Mexican food, but as every other review in here says, way over priced.  Thanks to all those expensive little boutiques on Fillmore, they have to charge $2 more on everything just to stay in business.  The carne asada is fresh and chunky, good guac as well.  The staff is very friendly too.
author: Darren A.

description:
While in SF, we ate at TacoBar because it looked good.  It kind of reminds me of an independent Baja Fresh.

I got a carne asada burrito ($7.95) with rice, pico de gallo, and no beans (they give me gas).  It's a fairly large burrito and it comes out hot and fresh.  

I don't really see anything spectacular about this place hence the 3 stars.

Cheers!
author: Mitch W.

description:
Exactly what the neighborhood needed a good Mexican place and now they serve breakfast! Yum! The staff is super friendly and attentive as well. 
Why only four stars? The prices are a bit high - it won't stop me from going but just saying...
author: Lovin S.

description:
I love TacoBar! It was so good! here are my pointers:
+2 for the ambiance and decorations. I think they were so cool!
+1 for the kindness of the staff. they let us in when they were closed.
+1 for the delicious food. I've never liked beans, but they made me like 'em
author: Malcolm M.

description:
Thoroughly unimpressed.

It's not as though I had high expectations going into my TacoBar experience, it averages 3 stars on Yelp; yet somehow TacoBar managed to fall short of my already low expectations.

I ordered the shrimp quesadilla which was decidedly lackluster and flavorless despite the $10 I paid for it. My friend got a salad and claims the only redeeming quality was the flavor of the jalapenos she had to pay to add.

Oh how I wish this TacoBar was Tacolicious instead!
author: Rachel R.

description: GREAT FOOD! My faves are the Tacos, especially baja fish. They give large pieces and the food is super fresh. I love their nachos! Crispy, not overly greasy with cheese. My husband love the shrimp quesadilla. Absolute favorite in PAC Heights. Not a fancy place but you can get good food and a normal price and not have to sit around for hours.
author: Katelyn D.

description:
Three stars is pretty accurate.

Tacos are extremely overpriced at $4 a taco (I think about $6 if you get the fixins) which does NOT include chips & salsa. Come on..a couple tortilla chips would have softened the blow of my $10 non-filling meal a little bit. 

But to be fair, the ingredients did taste somewhat fresh and seemed to be decent quality. The flavor wasn't as memorable as the hole in my wallet though.
author: Lele L.

description:
Alright, I know it's in SF, so I shouldn't expect reasonable prices, but honestly, nine dollars for a burrito is pushing it.  I would consider returning if it were amazing.  Unfortunately, it wasn't amazing.  :\

TacoBar is a cute little place on the corner of Fillmore and California.  I ordered the Baja Pescado burrito, which had beer-battered mahi mahi.  I will admit that the size of the burrito was huge (it lasted me two meals) and the fish was amazing and fresh (best part of the burrito).  Overall, however, it was quite salty and for the price, it didn't blow me away.

The horchata was pretty good, but again, I'm not sure I would buy it again for the price I paid.

I think I'll try other Mexican places in the area before deciding if I will return to TacoBar, but chances are I won't be inclined to come back often.
author: Can C.

description:
This place has a rocking Baja Burrito, which is beer battered mahi-mahi with a cabbage slaw and sauce. It was mighty tasty. We also order the Tortilla soup (meh) and the nachos (a little better). 

I'd stick to the Baja and order some chips and salsa. Oh and the Agua Frescas were refreshing as well!
author: Bri R.

description: I think most of the menu is quite overpriced for the quality (try the hidden gem; Poc Chuc in the mission on 16th between van ness and Shotwell for example for better quality AND value) but I write this review specifically because the vegetariana taco is AWESOME - grilled veggies, beans and guac are standard but  it's the crispy fried cheese shell that is just delicious... go to try this alone if not anything else!
author: Beth P.

description:
If this place wasn't so deceptive I would probably give it a slightly higher rating here, but unfortunately the way they have positioned this place you go in expecting a hip Tacolicious kind of place and end up getting a so so taqueria.  

My wife and I had an appointment nearby on California Street and wanted to grab some quick food because we had about 45 minutes to spare.  We had planned to eat inside but after circling around for 15 minutes looking for a parking spot with no luck, we parked in a yellow zone and my wife waited in the car (while I went inside) in case the dreaded meter maid decided to rear her ugly head.

Immediately after walking through the doors a friendly gentleman greeted me at the door and handed me a menu.  Based on his smile and his eagerness to please, I am pretty sure he is one of the owners of this joint.  There was also a menu board on the wall, but the annoying thing is that this menu didn't have any prices.  The paper menu I was handed was not designed well and was also unorganized (another annoyance). Since I am a born again vegetarian I asked the woman at the register (presumably the wife of said owner) what their vegetarian options were.  She told me about the burrito and the cheese quesadilla so I ordered both (burrito for my wife and quesadilla for me) as well as an order of guacamole, chips, apple juice, and diet coke.  I was shocked when she spit out the total of $25.50, but at that point I was starving and had little time to find anything else.

After waiting for 10 minutes, they handed me the bag of food and I opened it up to check if everything was there.  Good thing I did because they didn't include utensils or napkins (annoying).  

The food itself was ok and after eating it my wife and I both felt a little ill.  Not food poisoning ill, but just not right ill.  The food at this place is on par with those taquerias you find on every street corner in various parts of the Mission.  I would not recommend this place to anyone and you should just skip it.  The food is not so good and its definitely too expensive.
author: Ash S.

description:
Taco Bar is one of my favorite go-to restaurants for fast, fresh Mexican food.

The staff is friendly and accommodating. It has great ambiance, and it is very clean. 

I highly recommend the fish tacos and frescas.
author: Amber K.

description: I have been back here multiple times since my first, underwhelming visit (wife dragged me back initially). If you order the right items, the food is quite solid. Both the battered fish and battered shrimp tacos are delicious. The tortilla soup is outstanding!  Price points for this type of food is high, but it's necessary given the rent for a corner spot on Fillmore and California.
author: Samir N.

description: Nice fresh crispy chips and fresh flavorful salsa. Kids portions, especially burritos, were a generous size and nearly same size as adult version. Fried fish tacos were small but really nice, crispy flavorful fish and nice cream based sauce. Bottled and canned drinks were pricey, over $3 for jarritos soda. Juices are a nice touch, cucumber lime kills heat from spicy food well, but I will probably go with watermelon  or horchata next time.
author: Andy W.

description:
Ok so I love Mexican food, and I figured that this place should be in my wheel house so to speak. I had a quesadilla, a taco, and a few sangrias. First off, the sangrias. They were uniqure and genuine, with a large amount of fruit on the bottom that served as good snacking material once the drink had been consumed. But they were over $5 a piece for a lil cup! A bit pricey. Really too Pricey.

Next the taco. I go the fish taco, and while it was pretty good, the biggest problem with it was again the price, while the taco was good it wasn't amazing and I have certainly had better around SF for a more reasonable price ( even Tacolicious, which is the heart of the marina, 4 tacos over better quality can be had for $12, a price that beats Taco Bar) The biggest problem with the taco was that it seemed to rely too much on the sauce. It is as if the place was afraid to lean to heavily on the fish and the batter for the flavor and instead decided to let the sauce dictate the flavor. The photo I uploaded demonstrates this. Sauces should be like back up singers, they are important and can really bring a song to life, but you don't go to a concert to listen to Kate Perry's back up singers. You want the main event! And the amount of sauce on the taco interferes with letting the flavor of the fish take center stage.
 
The quesadilla was my favorite. Pretty well sized and made, it was a wonderful combination of flavors where, in contrast to the taco, all the flavors could be tasted and each contributed to a delightful flavor. However, it's a quesadilla. It should be the easiest Mexican food to make and should be good and would take a lot to really blow me away. (It has happened tho)
 
Overall, 3 stars. Very solid place, but I haven't had anything yet that would really push me to giving it 4. If I go back I will try something else and update. Hopefully we will be able to bump this up a bit.
author: Tom O.

description:
I've only had the tacos and they are excellent.   The fish are my favorite followed by the steak.  
The main negatives are the prices and small portions.  I need three tacos leading to $20 lunches.  It is in a high rent location.
author: John P.

description: If I still lived in the mission, I would never go to Tacobar. While I still stop in often enough when I can't go without a mexican meal, It pains me to pay 25% more in cash for ~50% of the taste you can get from any podunk taqueria in the mission. Fortunately for them, Pac Heights doesn't offer much in the way of competition and they do brisk business. If you do go in, let me point you towards the baja pescado or beef tounge tacos. They are solid but nothing to write home about.
author: Aaron M.

description: Went here today. Great customer service and quick food. Tried two items lamb taco was absolutely amazing and was the special. Yum. However the soup wasn't prepared as I was expected. Seemed to be tomato based. Used to a more natural broth and softer veggies. Good experience overall
author: Netta W.

description:
Decent place.. I've been here a few times for a quick meal and haven't really been impressed each time.  I mostly get the steak burrito, but have also gotten to try the 'Huevos a la Mexicana'.  The breakfast was decent, but I thought it was lacking for the price.

The burritos are pretty good but nothing really amazing.  They are around ~$9, which is pretty expensive, much like everything else on Fillmore.  I feel like I should get some chips or rice/beans or something on the side to compensate, but you must add all of that for something like $2+ each.  Definitely can't come here that often.

I would definitely recommend El Burrito Express on divisidaro over this for a much better value.  You can get a giant wet burrito for around $7 and it is just as delicious!


*I will say though, this place has really fresh, good tasting smoothies.. I've tried the blueberry, watermelon, and all of them taste like the fruits were freshly picked.. very delicious.
author: James M.

description: We're painting right around the corner and I decided to try this place out for lunch. (I am quite picky when it comes to Mexican restaurants) but this place has some amazing Baja Shrimp Tacos, well priced and the service by the girls is friendly and fast! Will definitely come back.
author: Gustavo R.

description: I've lived in the area for a while, and I kept craving mexican but thought Taco Bar was too trendy to be good.  Then, one night, CRAVING nachos, I went in.  Pretty tasty.... People were really nice, the food was good (although the salsas are in plastic squirt bottles??), very very small so difficult to find seating during meal rushes, but overall a good experience. I will go back to try other stuff.  I would have given it higher marks if there was more of a salsa selection and had more seating and I felt like each item ordered was worth the cost... I will go back because it's decent and close and allows me to get my Mexican craving without having to take the 22 to the Mission.
author: Kelby W.

description:
Cinco de Mayo is around the corner so I was in the mood for Mexican. TacoBar isn't my first choice for tacos especially after eating delicious street tacos in Cabo. Then again, there were no streetwalkers or stray cats staring at you. I digress.

Ordered the vegetarian tacos (one special and one regular). They fed my hunger and at almost $4/taco, I can make a better version. Lame, saving my taco funds for the Mission. 

Inside scoop: Bypass the two mild salsas served and ask for the "spicy" salsa (hidden in the back).
author: Sophie C.

description: Neat location in Pacific Heights.  The food was great.  The chips and guac was amazing!  The service was fast.  The dining area is a bit small, so expect to wait for a table if you come during the lunch rush.
author: Mark E.

description:
I'm only taking down one star because I think it's a little silly to charge for chips and salsa, when they come free at other Mexican establishments.

That aside, I'm disappointed that this place only has 3 stars - there should be more. Are San Franciscans now so snotty and spoiled that they can't cut Tacobar a break? Especially considering the other overly-priced French restaurants in the neighborhood that charge an arm and a leg for sandwich au jambon or croque monsieur? Pfffffffffftttttt. 

This place is great. They have sangria that doesn't suck (and that's hard to come by), affordable seafood tacos, and an open space that's great for informally meeting friends. They didn't even shoo me away when I finished my meal, said goodbye to one friend, and stuck around to read a book while I waited for another friend to grab a drink with me.

Seriously yelpers, get over yourselves and cut this place a break. Yeah, it's nothing you'd rave over if it were located in the Mission, but I'd rather eat here and enjoy the scenery than risk getting stabbed at the 16th or 24th St BART stations afterward.
author: Courtney S.

description: Thoroughly mediocre and expensive, TacoBar does the job, but doesn't go much farther.  I have eaten carne asada and carnitas burritos, chips & guac, and had their lime margaritas on several occasions, each time feeling my hunger/thirst quenched, but longing for a different burrito somewhere else which I had wished I were eating instead.  My wife left with a similar feeling from her tacos, but I was personally impressed with the crisped cheese outer shell- it was yummy.  I'm sure I will be back here- as I live nearby and I am often in the neighborhood for random reasons.  But this is a restaurant I will go to by geographical convenience only and not go out of my way for.
author: Andy S.

description: Hands down, the best tacos I have ever eaten.  All I could say as I was eating them was OMG.  The corn shells were ground by hand, the texture and flavor amazing.  Yes, expensive, but it is worth it for authentic Mexican ecstasy.  I will go back for more as often as I can.
author: Jenifer W.

description:
Bottom line: This place has delicious food! If you want just an ordinary cheap taco then go to chipotle. Sure it'll be a few dollars more here, but I think the taste is definitely worth it.

And its in Pac Heights, if you want to get the same level of food cheaper you'll have to go down to the mission. +$2 for muni fare and an hour of commuting and it amounts to the same thing!
author: Ash S.

description: We were walking down Fillmore trying to decide what to eat and took a chance at this place...so glad we did! Chicken taco salad and chicken quesadilla were yummy, not to mention the tasty chips!! Thumbs up, a great choice!
author: Donna E.

description:
I've been here a few times just before a movie at the theater down the street. It is a good quick bite. 
The burritos are tasty and way too big for one sitting. If you can manage sharing you'll leave full and cheap! :) 
The service is good. Everyone is helpful and friendly.
author: Dee C.

description: Excellent food! Baja tacos and tortilla soup was awesome! Please come to San Antonio Texas!
author: Donna K.

description: Baja Pescado and the quesadillas are the best. The burrito isn't that good. Pricy but pretty good and it's close to home. Probably wouldn't go out of my way to go here as I would for tacolicious.
author: Brian M.

description:
On the way back from walking around the city, I stopped by this place while heading home.  I ordered one pollo taco, chips and salsa, and a coke.  I paid almost $11 and all I have to say is Meh...

This is one of those learning experiences where you eat at a mediocre place and then you never eat there again for the next century.
author: Shad B.

description: My favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco. Super nice staff and its usually really quick. They have my burritos ready in less than 3 minutes usually.
author: Paul B.

description:
Not bad at all.. not in my list of top mexican places, but a pretty solid and consistent place for burritos.
The veggie burrito is pretty good, and really big and filling. They don't seem to give free chips with it, and don't seem to have a salsa bar either.. so a star off for that.
The coconut flan is pretty interesting.. not something i am really craving for, but nice to try once in a while... 4 stars for that too.
author: Aditya M.

description: Totally my favorite spot to pick up a basic burrito on my way home after meeting friends for drinks. What's the point of living in SF if you can't get a burrito the size of a Muni bus?
author: Kaylie P.

description:
You can be either good or reasonably priced and this place is neither. 

I don't really get the crispy cheese shell that came wrapped around my veggie taco, I think they called it a "cheese chicharron". Whatever it was it didn't taste very good and I wish they would have asked before they put it there. I guess reasonable people can disagree about that. 

I really didn't get their idea of "iced tea", it was red and tasted suspiciously like bad hibiscus. I asked the lady on the counter when it came if it was really iced tea and she was quite emphatic that it was. 

Overall I got the idea that they are trying to fancy it up to charge more but with gimmicks rather than flavors. Won't be coming back here again anytime soon.
author: Charlie S.

description: I know it's simple but I love their quesadillas -- black beans, rice, avocado and cheese. I can't explain why but it's better than ones I've had in the Mission. Their caesar salad dressing is pretty awesome too.
author: Lisi G.

description:
I hate to give bad reviews lately.  However, what can I say.  This place is what happens when you take cheap street food and try to convince highfalutin upper crusts that it is more valuable then it is.  I will include a picture below of the taco I got for 4 dollars.  I am pretty sure it was served on a 3 inch corn tortilla.  They had wrapped the cord tortilla with "cheese crisp".  Nice touch, but street food is great because of the flavor not the expense of the ingredients.  If you are going to try and elevate poor peoples food you better be damn good.  This place missed the mark.  
I would NEVER eat there again, patly out of principle and partly because the taco was just so-so.
author: Christopher F.

description: Decent food. Slightly over priced. Great location. No other Mexican food joints in the area.
author: Barry B.

description: Cute spot, delicious tacos, friendly efficient service. Margaritas were more sweet than stiff...am guessing they have a cordial license as opposed to full liquor.
author: Cec D.

description: So I'm half Mexican,  grew up eating delicious Mexican food. This slop they're serving up in California is a joke and Tacobar is a good example. I had a torta: bland and $10!!! For a torta?! Their tacos are americanized costal food.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
Turkey. Mole. Tacos. Hurry.

Available for a limited time only. No problem to replace rice with black beans, and loved the sesame seed accents.

Fourth star earned for delicious originality.
author: Jason B.

description:
Today was my first time at taco bar. I live relatively close so I called in an order and did take out. The Baja Pescado taco was amazing!! Then I ran I to a bump in the road when they forgot to put guacamole and sour cream in my burrito.

I called and they checked the ticket and I applaud them for their customer service. They realized they messed up and actually walked to my house and delivered a new burrito. You don't get much better service and the food was good. I would recommend this place to anyone!

Thanks taco bar :)
author: Pat W.

description:
My over-priced $8 Burrito was bland and boring. 
The only thing that I enjoyed are the chips.
author: Kirill E.

description:
I started going to TacoBar about a month ago.  I am always looking for the best burrito I can get with reasonable parking, a shop that is easy to get in and out of and that is close to my house.  I eat burritos almost every night.....these things are critical. 

TacoBar spikes really highly on the old in and out, they handle phone orders super well and you can park in Mollies parking, no worries.  Wait, I can park in Mollies no worries.  You shouldn't.  It's unethical.  And Bob, Mollies resident panhandler, might tell on you....

So, TacoBar spikes super high on the ease of use side, how about the burrito?  It's good.  I wasn't sold my first time in, it has an unusual kinda salty flavor that I wasn't sure I loved.  But strangely, a day went by, then another day and I found myself craving said strange salty flavor.  They got me with the cheese.  So I started going back fairly regularly.  The people are friendly, the chips are good.  All good stuff.

Which in sum equates to about 3 stars......maybe 4, but TacoBar did something last night that went above and beyond.  

One more aside:  I absolutely hate Sour Cream.  Like despise Sour Cream.  The only thing in the world I hate more is Mayonnaise (and the Dodgers I guess but that's unrelated).

Ok, onward.  My wife stopped to pick up burritos for us last night.  My super no sour cream and her veggie thing.  When she gets home I take a bite and worst possible scenario, tons of sour cream up in my burrito.  Ahhh, sour cream. I'm bitter but reasonable. I eat a lot of burritos, these things happen.  They don't happen to me cause I hover over the counter and monitor the burrito making process, but they do happen.

We call and tell them what happened expecting to have to go pick up a new burrito and what do they do?  Deliver a brand spanking new, sour cream free burrito to my apartment in like 10 minutes (literally) with a free dessert.  You know this is a burrito shop, not a pizza delivery place, right.  Just checking.  

I was blown away and will be a customer for life, or until Mollies starts cracking down on the use of their parking lot.......
author: Eamonn T.

description:
Have given it a couple trys and its just not that good... food is bland and totally over priced for what you get. Super small portions. If you add the fried cheese and guacamole to your order the food tasts better, but I hate having to add all that extra fat just for good mexican food. 

Skip it...
author: Maddy D.

description: Not your classic taqueria but a refreshing alternative with fantastic drinks and a killer quesadilla con camaroñes. Fresh ingredients and friendly staff, fulfills a craving in the Pac Heights neighborhood.
author: J D.

description: Considering this is the only place you can really get a burrito in pac heights (unless you venture to the Divis area), I'd give it 3 stars. But really, it's more a 2-star place. You have the standard burritos and tacos, but nothing is spectacular. It may satisfy your craving for a bit, but you're better off just going to mission and being much happier.
author: Angela S.

description:
The food is good.  Tasty.  Decent quality.  The guy who seems to be the owner seems friendly enough.

The menu has no prices, which was just plain annoying.  Then my partner and I ordered what for any other Mexican restaurant would be plenty of food.  It came to an appalling $28, and when it arrived, we became immediately deflated.  The portions were so tiny, they were like appetizers.  Tiny appetizers.  I'm sorry but $4 for a taco that is two bites?  Seriously, a 3" tortilla? The rice, ($3 extra) was in a tiny ramiken...four forkfuls.

When my (Mexican) partner commented to the waitress about it, she apologized and said these are the size of the tortillas in Mexico.  He laughed out loud.

The people at the next table had a similar disappointment.  When their orders came, the gentleman returned to the counter to order more food.  We left and got dinner afterward for half the price of these appetizers.

For cafeteria style service in a joint with canned soda this is not acceptable.  Skip this and go to Little Chihuahua instead.
author: Denis P.

description: I had their famous taco and shrimp burrito.  The burrito had 4 shrimp in it!  What a joke.  If you want real Mexican food, your better off going to the Mission!
author: Ammala B.

description: Not really feeling this over priced mexican joint. Workers are friendly but the food it ain't all that! I understand that they're in the Fillmore with these high prices but I rather go all the way to the mission for some good Mexican food.
author: Marilyn W.

description: A small street taco stand that had good chips and salsa but the tacos were ok and not as spicy as I would have liked, and the price did not justify the portion. The service was ok and the environment kind of boring.
author: Patrick C.

description:
If this place weren't a mere half block from my apartment, I'd probably never have stopped in.

Don't get me wrong, the chips and salsa are great. In fact, if I'm ever looking for just chips and salsa, Tacobar would be in my top-8 SF choices. Anything else? I'll probably pass.

The best entree I've had here was definitely the veracruz pescado burrito: not too crazy heavy and the fish is generally pretty tasty. Everything else I've tried - from the salads (way too heavily dressed) to the quesadillas (pretty bland) to the tortilla soup (tasty, but nothing out of this world) has been fairly average - and not all that cheap for what it is. With La Mediterranee down the street offering cheap, fresh food with a heck of a lot more flavor, I typically pass on the TB
author: Amanda F.

description:
This review is solely for their vegetarian burrito and chips/salsa.

I am a vegetarian and I am writing to say that their veggie burritos are the most delicious and healthiest burritos I've had since moving up to San Francisco.

Compared to El Burrito Express four blocks down the street (their vege and fresh mix burritos), Tacobar's vege burritos are consistently not greasy, scalding hot, or prone to falling apart. They go great with their red and green salsa too.

However, they are smaller and more expensive, but I am willing to pay for it. And if you're wise enough to read the menu about the vege burrito at Tacobar, it's made with Pinto beans (non vegetarian.) Simple solution -- ask for black, which they substitute.


The chips and salsa are also really great too.
author: Shaun D.

description: Breakfast burrito with chorizo is always a welcome weekend treat! Chilaquiles Rojos is also pretty good. A little pricey but mostly worth it.
author: Brian R.

description:
Wow! That was the most expensive burrito I've ever eaten in San Francisco! I've had fantastic ones in the Mission for one-third the price.

It was the saltiest burrito I've had probably ever. The refried beans were mysteriously thick and sticky. I requested mild-salsa, but I got spicy. 

I paid a $1.75 extra for guacamole they left out, when I showed them they gave me a little container, I don't understand how you could make guac soooo bland. 

Maybe they think they're upscale because of their cute plates and the extra heavy foil they wrap the burritos in? 

The service is not rude, but neither friendly, unless you're a cute girl about twenty. I will not be going back even if I am extremely hungry in the Fillmore.
author: Walt A.

description: I love this little place for a no-frills baja fish taco or a shrimp quesadilla.   The margarita is pretty good also.  They are fast and friendly, and very casual.  The nachos are great!
author: Jason S.

description: You really have to be hungry to pay the prices for this food! I went in and ordered two taco's and a soda.. since I don't like beans that come with it I asked if I could have rice for which I was told no... then they had the nerve to charge me nearly 9 bucks for two measly taco's!  This may be the biggest rip off in the city! Go to the mission where you can get 10 tacos for that price!
author: Daniel J.

description: The shrimp quesadillas and mahi tempura tacos were delicious.  The jicama grapefruit salad was ok- not my fav.
author: Duke D.

description: Way too expensive for the tacos.  The fish in the fish tacos was good but it was mostly veggies.  I prob wouldnt come here again.
author: V L.

description: Great food but pricey. Check out the beer battered fish burrito. it's delicious!
author: Matt K.

description: 4 stars cause its a bit pricey, but its worth every cent. Finally some authentic amazing mexican food thats not all the way out in the mission! Kudos for the nice staff and having a chorizo breakfast burrito!
author: Kristina B.

description: This is the second stopped for me in this part of the upper Fillmore area. Very small tacos, be warned. Better order 2 for a very light lunch. They offer organic and fresh ingredients and natural beef/pork etc. which is why the higher cost than "non-organic" meats. I got to admitted, they were pretty good tacos and tasty though.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I miss my La Salsa. It was our go-to place for us UOP students after a long day at school. This new taco bar place is just too fancy for me. 4 bucks for taco and 10 bucks for a burrito. Me no likey :(

The flavors are lacking in their meats and their salsas are lame. I would much rather walk a little bit and get my fat ass to burrito express
author: Emily T.

description:
My favorite Mexican joint in my brand new city of San Francisco!
I don't know what the bad reviews are all about but I am all for this place.
The servers are so sweet and the atmosphere is very inviting.

Beware though, this place is highly addicting.

I love Taco bar for its simple, no frills approach to fresh, delicious Mexican food. Carne Asada and Mahi Mahi are among my favorites. The Mahi Mahi is fresh, flavorful and paired with perfect, crunchy bites of cabbage. You can get any of the tacos "Special"- meaning with guacamole and cheese. What's cool is that instead of shredded sprinkles of cheese, this place makes a crunchy crust of cheese that they stick to the outside of your corn flour taco. GENIUS. I like their food because it's not greasy but always tasty. Not to mention that green sauce is MONEY. 

It's pricier considering what you pay at hole-in-the-walls in the Mission but hey, you're in Pac Heights...at a clean restaurant...what did you expect?
author: Lianne Z.

description:
More like 3.5 stars, but closer to 3 than 4.

Lower Pac Heights isn't flush with Mexican food, so I dropped in today to see how it was. I ordered the standard carne asade burrito, chips/salsa, and a bottle of Coke ($15.50). 

The burrito was large but not overly so, but was noticeably devoid of much spice and flair. The steak was definitely higher quality than most taquerias. The salsa was good, but the chips/salsa side is really meant for two people. 

All in all, solid but unspectacular. And certainly a bit pricey for what you get.
author: Scott L.

description:
I'm a little surprised at the bad reviews. Tried Taco Bar for the first time and was pleasantly surprised.

Great flavor to the three different tacos I tried.

1. Short rib taco - it was on the special board and it was pretty tasty. A little on the polite side but it's short ribs.

2. Camarones - good solid shrimp taco with mangoes in the salsa.

3. Veggie - a outer cheese tortilla! Surprised and surprisingly good flavor.

Need to try more of the natural meat tacos but needless to say, I'll be back.

Extra props for their chips and salsa. Fresh and with good kick.
author: June C.

description:
Its Ok.
The tacos aren't very traditional but they aren't too original either.
The Aguas Frescas are pretty good, but nothing out of this world.
If you are looking for a midweek lunch, its ok. But there are far more memorable places down this street.
author: Gonzalo M.

description: Food is solid here. I ordered the shrimp tacos and my friend had the quesadilla. I also ordered the world's smallest margarita here haha. The drink was literally half of a glass so I was a little disappointed. My tacos were good but my friend's quesadilla was very good. I'd probably stick to other Mexican places in the city when I need a fix
author: Sheeva G.

description: Baja Pescado Burrito = amazing. Large portion size, fresh, delicious.
author: Charles G.

description:
The food is absolutely wonderful.. Real authentic mexican eats right on the corner of Fillmore and California. 
The prices match my expectation for Fillmore but the management and customer service combined with the quality of the food makes it all with it and then some. 
Give it a try!
author: Gianna J.

description:
Go for the Veracruz Pescado Taco.  Great flavor!
I tasted the Carnitas as well but I'm not a big fan of shredded beef.  
Great new addition to the Fillmore District.  Will be back for the Burros and Quesadillas.  Maybe today!  ;)
author: John W.

description:
You would think I would save money on lunch, working from home as often as I do. After all, what else are all those leftovers doing in my refrigerator??

Alas, this is not the case. Because TacoBar is 3 blocks away. So whenever I work from home, I inevitably end up down the street ordering 2 Baja Pescado tacos and a Coke. And man, it's worth it every. single. time. Even if it does negate the money I saved on gas that morning.

Everyone here is super friendly, the restaurant is extremely clean, and while the tacos don't quite measure up to Tortilla Heights (Nick's Way, of course), they still completely satisfy my never-ending fish taco craving. Also, the red salsa is delicious, and the prices are great.
author: Jessica O.

description:
I call bullshit on that "Taco Especial" for $1.65!  You add a little guac and then some chewy, fried cheese wrap on the outside of my corn tortilla!  Am I supposed to eat this thing?  It's gross.  I would have preferred you put a little cotija inside and sent me on my way.  Either way, I don't give a shit what you think you are entitled to!

Okay, that got a little out of hand.  Pulled a little Jack from nowhere.  

The best thing that I consumed was my cold Diet Coke, which they very nicely provided for me in a glass with ice.  It was awesome.
author: Tamar D.

description:
I stumbled up on this place off of fillmore and decided to try it. It was smack in the middle of lunch time so it was definitely packed. I tried the shrimp tacos but they weren't that good and pretty dry. The shrimps themselves were good but all together not so much. I also had the ice tea and it was very bland.
But I looked around at other plates around me and it looked tasty so I might give it a try one more time.
author: Lana K.

description:
I'm going to keep this short and sweet.

the food is friggin good. perhaps the people that had bad experiences here went on a bad day? its possible right?

I've gone here a few times and everytime I have...i've eaten well and not paid a ton of money.

the ONLY gripe I have and its a pretty significant one...is the sour cream. I think its not 100% natural as every time I do use it...I have to run home and ...well you know.

so now...i just ask for my food without it.
author: Dean M.

description:
I really wanted to be a fan of this place - when I saw it being built, I was ecstatic. This morning, when I checked the reviews, I chalked the low ratings up to "lower pac height snobs" who were expecting too much out of a taco place. Unfortunately, I have either become one of those folks, or, as I suspect, this place isn't marketing itself well.

TacoBar makes you think it will be a down-to-earth taco place, however, it's actually a pseudo-gourmet take on Mexican food. That alone doesn't give it the low rating, though - it's the price mixed with the attitudes mixed with the poor explanations of what you are getting.

When my boyfriend and I ordered, we got 2 carnitas tacos, a carne asada quesadilla with the extra crema fresca and guacamole, and chips and salsa. A lot of people on here complained about the price of chips, but for the quality of chip and salsa, they were amazing. However, the guy in front of me got his salsa and some cheese heaped on the chips, and I got a relatively small pot of salsa. I had to ask why mine were different than his, and they said "oh you have to ask for that" which I didn't understand (how would I know that?) and then I had to ask for the cheese. I thought the guac came with the chips, but that was my mistake, and I was fine with that.

We sat outside (not a ton of seating, but it's a nice place inside) and besides the really annoying guy's barking dog (people, don't go to a restaurant and tie your dog up. You are a jerk when you do this) it was really nice. I was annoyed that when I tried to use a squeeze bottle for the salsa, the top wasn't screwed on and it all poured out everywhere, but again, small thing. 

My biggest disappointment was the main course. My boyfriend had tacos, which he said were fine - the pork was a little bland and a little dry. However, my "quesadilla" was not a quesadilla. At first we thought I got a burrito in some flakey kind of flatbread. I inquired as to where my sour cream and guac were (every quesadilla I've ever gotten has the pico de gallo, sour cream, and guac on the side and that's why I love them) and the woman went back in to get them. She didn't return - instead a guy who I believe was the owner came. He showed me my receipt and told me I never ordered guacamole, and I said "I got this with the special extra" and he said "that's not the same as guacamole. You have to pay a lot of money for that." 

I thought that was a really weird and rude thing to say, so I told him he should explain his menu better and he pointed at my food and said "I can see guacamole in there." Then he left.

There was, indeed, something resembling a little guacamole inside my not-quesadilla, but it was such a pathetic amount that I will say that no one should get the extra - for two bucks a glop of sour cream and a tiny green coloring of guacamole isn't worth it. Avocado isn't gold, people. 

Overall, however, I didn't like the quesadilla. The tortilla wasn't a tortilla, it was shaped like a burrito and difficult to eat, and overall this take on fusion wasn't what I was expecting nor what I would have ordered had I know. Couple that with the rude owner and the lack of explanations, I'm never going back to this place. 

If you guys can get your attitudes in order and figure out a good system for selling things that doesn't leave people confused and feeling ripped off, I'll come back. I have no qualms paying $25 like I did today for the meal I had - I just don't want to feel verbally assaulted by the owner because I asked where my sides were. Food isn't a fine art. It's food.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Came here looking for a new place to dine on Fillmore for a light lunch.  TacoBar, you hit the spot!  I got the nachos, and my husband got the fish tacos.  Both were really delicious and flavorful. And for someone who hates onions and cilantro, I like that you don't bury the fish underneath all that for your fish tacos.  The nachos had a good mix of chips, cheese, beans, crema, and avocado so that it wasn't greasy or too dry.  The service was really great and very attentive.  Looking forward to coming back here again.
author: Julie P.

description:
Being new to San Francisco I am on the search for the best fish taco. While I didn't find the best fish taco at Taco Bar I did find what I would consider a pretty darn good vegetarian taco. It has a very different type of shell that is hard to explain (hard and soft kind of) and they put tons of guacamole on it. The shrimp taco was tastier than the white fish which I found to lack flavor. The space was clean, service good, and tons of single people that seemed to feel comfortable sitting on stools and eating alone.

I noticed other people's reviews commented on the price being high. For three taco's the cost was $11.95.
author: Kathy J.

description:
I am no taco nor Mexican food expert, but I know what taste good to me. I probably like the watered down version of Mexican food, since i hate grease and don't like tacos unless they are from Mexico, but I liked this place. 

I ordered a carnitas burrito on a whole wheat tortilla and black beans. Wow, the pork was abundant and juicy. I pretty much couldn't stop myself from taking bite, after bite. I guess the place is a bit pricey, but isn't everything in that neighborhood? 

I would have to say that this place is not worth over looking, and take it for what it is. You order a taco or burrito and it hits the spot. I don't think that it is life-changing but not every place is. I commend this place for delivering good quality food... bravo!
author: Tiffany L.

description: 2.5 stars. Their Baja pescado burro is as good as a fish burrito gets (5 stars)- absolutely delicious and the only reason this rating is as high as it is. But I'm trying to eat a little healthier than fried food so I have been branching out and have been disappointed each time. The grilled fish burro is ok (3.5 stars). The grilled shrimp burro was not worth the time or calories to eat it. Maybe 5 shrimp, a fruit salsa that added much-needed sweetness on the few moments I could taste it. The burrito was mainly cabbage slaw- overly pickled, assertive cabbage slaw that overpowered everything else and made the burrito taste like one note. Crunchy pickle wrapped in a tortilla is not what I was expecting for lunch today.
author: Esembee B.

description:
Man, this place.... What a toss up.

Pluses
- I thought the Carnitas was very tasty
- The Carne Asada was also pretty good
- Interesting deserts including a variety of weird ice creams (tequila flavored for instance)
- Nice decor
- A nice smoky, chipotle taco sauce
- A good variety of mexican beers, sodas, horchata, etc.

Minuses
- Freaking too expensive for what you get
- Not enough standard toppings for burritos. By default they get rice, beans, pico, meat...  Everything else is extra or not available.
- Pretty slow getting orders out to you

The problem is that all of the Pluses are things I expect as a STANDARD so the Minuses win here and 2 stars it is.  In reality I'll probably still go here from time to time since it's close to my house and the burritos/tacos taste ok as long as you stay away from fish, but I'll definitely seek out other opportunities as they arise.
author: Nicholas N.

description:
I ordered a steak burrito and a coke and was charged $15

When I got my burrito in consisted of steak and cole slaw.  Cole slaw?

No beans, no rice, no salsa, no nothing.  a tiny bit of steak cubes and a whole bunch of cole slaw.  I took two bites that were all cole slaw.  I grabbed a fork and shredded through the whole burrito and it looked like the soggy lettuce at the bottom of a plate of Chow Mein.

Disgusting.
author: Bumbaklot R.

description:
I went back and forth, but, ya know, I've eaten here a few times now and I'm going to give this place a solid five stars. 

The food: Damn good fish tacos and burritos. The ingredients are fresh and well balanced, and an obvious cut above standard taqueria food. The portions are pretty big, and I definitely feel like I get my money's worth. 

The chips: For crying out loud, people, shut up about free chips. No, they don't give away free chips, but honestly, do you really need to stuff your face with free cheap-ass tortilla chips when you're already ingesting, like, a thousand calories? Grow up. If you want chips, buy them, and Tacobar's chips are amazing (read: homemade, not out of a giant plastic bag). If you order the chips, salsa and guac it's a meal in itself. "Oh! La Salsa gave us free chips!" Yeah? Get over it. 

The service: Speaking of La Salsa, most of the people who worked there are here now. It's nice to see familiar faces. Smart move by the owner in keeping them around. 

Overall, a great addition to the neighborhood. Solid!
author: Mark G.

description: Baja pescado taco is where it's at. Delicious succulent fish, mouth watering sauces, corn tortillas, what could be better?  Knocked a star off because it's a bit pricey
author: kitty c.

description:
Corn con queso? Free-range chicken? Hell yeah.
My first time here, I had a margarita, chicken quesadilla, and corn on the cob (which had cotija cheese, lime and chili-delicious). I was highly impressed with the food. However, I was disappointed by the margarita and would not recommend getting one if you decide to eat here.

The second time I went, I enjoyed my choice of entree more. Though the chicken quesadilla tasted great, the veracruz tacos were amazing. I topped both with the different salsas they had (my favorite being the red one, which has a hint of BBQ to it). The fish wasn't overdone and the portions filled me up.

Reasons to go here:
1. CORN IN THE CUP
2. Veracruz tacos
3. Cheese quesadilla 

A refreshingly cheap spot to dine along the Fillmore =)
author: Surge C.

description:
Pro:
1. Chicken is well grilled (very tasty)

Con:
1. Overpriced
2. Chips and salsa are extra
3. Making it Especial is the only way to give their food more flavor that makes it even more expensive

Overall:
Overpriced for less than decent food, I would much rather walk a few blocks to burrito express or jump on a bus to nick's crispy tacos for better mexican food
author: Chirag V.

description: I'm full and I just ordered another shrimp taco. The line caught (yeh) mahi mahi taco also rocks. Best I've had in the Bay area. Why? Fresh, not greasy, clean, spicy marinades, you can taste the flavors of the fish and shrimps. Salsas are great. Tortillas are nothing special, they could make their own but it's ok. The woman next to me ordered a Veracruz burrito without a tortilla, I'm doing that next time!
author: Karma R.

description:
really pricey considering the portions are small and it's mexican food...
got the chicken tacos with a side of guac and they were moist, flavorful, and really filling despite the small size. loved that they had a variety of fresh juices like watermelon and cucumber lime. i'd definitely come here again if i happen to be shopping around fillmore, but i don't think id make a special trip here
author: Stephanie C.

description: This place is cute aesthetically but the food hails in comparison to any real Taqueria! Expensive too. No chips or salsa bar? Thumbs down
author: Jonah W.

description:
It feels weird to give only two stars to a place I've been to three times in the past month, but I think that's more just a reflection of me wanting something quick and Mexican to eat in the neighborhood. 

The food, as others have noted, isn't actually bad. It's just that it's pricey.  I've tried the soft tacos and burritos, and if you're coming, I'd recommend the soft tacos, which taste fresh and well seasoned. Plus going with the soft tacos gives you a chance to order a several (3 will probably fill you up) so chances are you'll like at least one of them.  It's not bad, but when I think about the best tacos I've ever had at a street corner restaurant (La Esquina in NYC), there's no comparison.  

Still, I wouldn't be surprised if I'm back there in the next month, just because there's not a lot of Mexican options in the area.   If there were a Chipotle nearby, this place would be out of business.
author: John H.

description:
OHMYGOD.
why are people giving tacobar so much shit!
indeed it is a bit pricey but everything is organic and local.
which is good for us/the environment/ the animals i have no clue why this doesn't please Pac Heights Residents?!
i ordered the chicken nachos which were SUPREME for like 9-ish dollars which i split with a friend after not eating for 8 hours. They were indeed filling, crispy chips, flavorful chicken and guacamole. ITS ALL GOOD.
Tacobar is fasho one of the greatest.
author: Camilo D.

description:
We didn't have too many expectations coming into Tacobar. After braving the grub-tastic, hipsterrific taquerias in the Mission, being served Mexican food by a Caucasian on Fillmore St. (for $4 a taco no less) didn't seem like one of the best decisions ever. But, the hubby wanted Mexican and didn't want to drive to the Mission, so here we were. 

I actually lucked out and ordered what had to be the best taco on the menu - a special of braised beef marinated in ancho chilli and served up with a creamy sauce and chopped cabbage. I also had a pretty delicious Veracruz fish taco - spicy grilled as opposed to breaded Baja style. Delish and just the right amount to get me to that happy place.

Not so lucky was dear hubby, who in his hunger opted for a carnitas "burro" (slightly smaller size burrito) that was  sorely lacking in meat. We sliced into it and came up with nada by way of protein, just a squishy mess of rice, beans and guac. There must have been all of 3 carnitas cubes in there, which considering the $6 price tag was no bueno. I asked him how it tasted and after a pause, he just said, "It tastes... white." Nuff said.

And, we had to pay separately for chips AND salsa, which weren't half as good as the free stuff you get in the Mission (or Papalote for that matter). WTF amigos?

Lesson learned: order the tacos at Tacobar, and enjoy the clean atmosphere, cute service staff, and Fillmore St. ambiance. But only if you're too cheap, hungover, or baked to make it down to the Mission.
author: Michi V.

description:
This place is ok. When we walked by, there was a really long line of people waiting to order. When we discovered that everywhere else had an hour or longer wait for lunch, we walked back in the direction of TacoBar. Lo and behold, the line was reasonable and there was an open table outside (we brought our poochie with us).

Hubby got a carne asada burrito and really enjoyed it. I got the vegetarian tacos and was a little underwhelmed. They had this baked cheese crisp inside of a corn tortilla, topped with pinto beans, pico de gallo, and guacamole. I asked for the guac to be left off but they left it on. On well. 

I wanted to like the crispy cheese more but it lacked something- salt maybe. Also, I POURED red salsa all over my tacos and it added...nothing. I LOVE salsa- and most sauces for that matter- and was disappointed that there really wasn't anything to it.

We'll see if we come back here.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Eh..Tacobar didn't meet my expectations.  I'm not sure why I didn't check the Yelp reviews prior to getting food here, but I guess the name itself was convincing enough.  I grabbed a carnitas burrito with the works and paid about $10.00.  Waaay overpriced for what it was.  I've gotten burritos for almost half the price that tasted twice as good.  For 10 bucks I was expecting something quite fantastic, but it failed.  I also got a corn appetizer with some lime, cheese, and chili powder - this was also just ok and was a bit too watery for me.  I was expecting something more creamy.  I must admit that the RED sauce was pretty good - it had a nice chipotle flavor.  The green sauce was a bit too cilantro-y for me.

Individual tacos are $3.75 EACH...I can get 3 delicious tacos at my fav truck for that price!!!  My meal was about $15 (no drink included) - I don't think I'm coming back anytime soon.  Too bad because this is the only "Mexican" place in the area.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
TacoBar is the only Mexican food in the area, so beggars can't be choosers. I loved the woman who took my order and politely spoke Spanish with me despite my gringaness!  I got the vegetariano burrito with black beans. Mushrooms were EXCELLENT. Good ratios of tortilla to beans to rice to pico. That said, everything was EXTREMELY salty. 

I also believe that with the PREMIUM price for the burrito, they should jump on the mission wagon and add some chips to the $8+ burrito.

I will go back and pray for less salt:)
author: Lauren R.

description: Yummm!!! I am Mexican Caesar Salad's number 1 fan and this place has made the cut! My brother and I went there today and it was great! I'll be back :) thx TacoBar!
author: Mya C.

description:
So we had 2 tacos each, a sangria and a margarita.. $33. Kinda insane.

The margarita was very delicious though, and the presentation on it was delightful.

Tacos were so-so. For a place called Taco Bar, I really expected them to be all about tacos and provide many different kinds of tacos. Alas, it wasn't so. They have only standard tacos here, no creative twists or anything.

Otherwise, the place was clean and comfortable, and the service was good. I like that they give you the sauces in the squeeze bottle thing.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Living nearby and a serious craving for chips and guac meant it was time to make my first pilgrimage to the only mexican place in the Lower Pac Heights neck of the woods (well on the Fillmore corridor anyway). 

First order of business (and the reason I was there in the first place)...

CHIPS + GUAC :: Pretty solid overall. Thick chips. Not greasy. Creamy guacamole. 

Next up...

VERACRUZ FISH TACO :: Not a fan. The salsa was a tomato sauce consistency which left the tortilla soggy. It also seemed almost sweet...? There's another fish taco option - hoping it's better! Relatively small for the price too. 

Finally...

VEGGIE BURRITO :: Huge. Absolutely giant. Like 3 meals worth of food. Average but nothing to write home about on taste...so doubt I'd want it for that second (or third) meal. 

Will I be back? Maybe. 
I'll just stop myself after ordering chips/salsa/guac.
author: Lauren S.

description:
YUM!!

Korean short rib tacos with horseradish, spicy shrimp tacos and guacamole and chips for less than $20. Could life get any better?
author: Leanne S.

description:
It is important that you know I generally dislike Mexican food or the Tex-Mex that passes for Mexican cuisine throughout most of the U.S.

TacoBar is bright and cheerful. The staff is welcoming and friendly and the prices are affordable.

It is the most delicious burro (different type of burrito) that I have ever eaten that compels me to write. The quality of the ingredients, care in preparation, and imaginative components create exceptional food that is beyond delicious. The grilled shrimp were incredibly fresh, sweet, lightly seasoned, and served in a tortilla with perfect shredded cabbage and mango salsa. It was scrumptious, flavorful, and unlike an ordinary burrito.

Shredded cabbage? Yes, a vegetable I usually avoid. Tacobar uses it as an incredibly crisp accompaniment inside the burro, which added texture, crunch, and balance to the lightly seasoned shrimp and spicy mango salsa.

Hibiscus Iced Tea was the perfect beverage. I plan on eating here every time I'm in the neighborhood. Ok, the competition in this neighborhood for delicious, healthy, and affordable food is intense. Between Woodhouse, La Meditteranee, Troya, Jane, and La Boulange, TacoBar is probably the least expensive, offers the most flavorful, and quickest meals.
author: P. B.

description: The staff are really pleasant and nice, and the food is pretty good.  There is somewhat a lack of spiciness and flavor -- I had the carne asada tacos, and all it needed was a little kick to make it a bit tastier.  Also, wish the carne asada was a little more shredded -- the bigger pieces made it a bit more difficult to eat.
author: Mel G.

description:
It's sad, because TacoBar's food is great but horrible for the price. Expect small portions and a sinking feeling that you should have gone somewhere on Polk street.

I go to TacoBar occasionally because it is close.
author: Sean F.

description:
Horchata = A+
Vegetarian Taco = B+

I swung by last night with my boo on our Fillmore Street eatery tour.  I guess the biggest criticism that everyone seems to share is that, compared with all of the other more AUTHENTIC Latin eateries in this city, this is not one of them.

However, that being said, it was very tasty and the price was right!  I got the vegetarian taco.  The vegetables were done just right, and the guac they put on top was insanely green and fresh.  It was very tasty and satisfying, and I would come back here to get more if I were in the hood and craving something Mexican inspired.
author: Kyle T.

description:
I am a serious burrito connoisseur and quite frankly I was happy to see a non-chain taco/burrito spot come into my neighborhood but you are WAY too expensive...
I can get an awesome burrito in the mission at a ton of different places for $5-7 with guacamole, etc...

I can go to Papalote or Ocean Taqueria and get an amazing burrito for $7-8 but you charge $10 because you're in Pac Heights?? come on... you're not Mamacita...

And I tried to give you another chance and had a taco there yesterday.. I've had tacos all over the place and usually one comes with enough meat, beans, etc. to fill me up for like $5.. I would have needed 3 from you ($15) to fill me up..

Sorry but you've lost my business...
author: Christopher H.

description:
Seeking an inexpensive and quick dinner option along Fillmore St., I remember an email that mentioned the opening of a new Mexican joint where the old La Salsa used to be.  So we gave it a walk-by and decided that we'd give it a go.  However, we were severely disappointed.

Disclaimer: I love the stuff that you can get from a taco truck, whether it's in the Mission, SOMA or the one that's right beside Gap corporate offices along the Embarcadero.  For the quality and the cheap prices, I usually use these trucks as a benchmark.

That said, I saw the menu at Tacobar and thought... "Ah, these are pretty decent prices for a TWO-taco plate....". But much to my disappointment... the price reflect one for ONE stinkin' taco. STRIKE ONE.

Once we got our food (my wife got the grilled Mahi Mahi taco, I got the chicken burrito and our lil' one got a bean and cheese burrito... nino sized!), we sat down and started to eat... But then noticed the table next to us with chips and salsa... so I walked up to the counter to ask for a bowl of C'n'S.... "Sorry, you have to pay for that."... Um, but I just spent like $6 for A stinkin' taco....   STRIKE TWO

Then the taste.... nothing specatucular, and as you would think, lots of filler (rice and beans) in my burrito.  The wife's fish taco was okay at best.  Our daughter however, loved the beans in her burrito and the tortilla (wasn't too crazy about the cheesy cheese).  So STRIKE 2 and a half.

Would I come back here?  NO... I'd rather go chase down a taco truck.
author: Dale K.

description:
So far I've tried the baja pescado, carne asada & vegetariano especial...all three are so, so yummy.  But here's the truly mind blowing thing.  The vegetariano especial came in a soft taco shell inside a crispy shell made of CHEESE.  What is this taco technology they have going on?!?  Mind blowing.  A crispy shell of cheese.  Freal?

The nachos are also amazing, made so by the house-pickled jalapenos.  You'll want to order a side of them to put on *everything*.  So, so good.
author: Emily T.

description:
Mexican food designed and priced for yuppies.  The veggie taco I had was tasty and unique, but it was only 2 bites. And it was $4. Very bad value considering the number of equally good alternatives in this city. I didn't find the fried cheese wrapper to be as interesting as I hoped. 

 Even the tacos at the equally expensive ferry building are filling. I may drop in again for something more substantial, like a burrito. But at $8 a pop I'm not getting my hopes up.
author: Mark F.

description:
I, too, like many other yelpers was excited of the Taco Bar opening.  I missed my La Salsa fixes and was very happy to learn that some of the unemployed La Salsa staff was working at Taco Bar.  I wish it could be a different reality with this place.... it's terrible.

I went the week they opened to try it and although I'm not too picky, the menu seemed rather vague and lacked details.  There are desert items and horchata beverages listed by the cash register,  but you wouldn't notice through a crowd.  You think the street signs are unclear in Mexico?  Try Tacobar.

I decided to go with the Tortilla Soup, for a sky-rocketed $7.95.  This is not a restaurant, nor is the atmosphere restaurant-like.  It's supposed to be a high-end Mexican cantina.  Well, at modest Mexican cantinas I get chips & salsa, and when I ask for water I'm given a real glass of water -- Tacobar insists you buy bottled water, or you can self-serve yourself with a freakin' DIXIE CUP OF WATER!  I'm not rinsing and spitting for my dentist, yo!  I'm paying $9 bucks for bland and too salty soup without chips and salsa while sitting in a corner with my knees hitting the wall!  You think that shopping and driving in Mexico are an altered state of reality?  Try Tacobar.

I suspected I was expecting too much my first visit, so I gave Tacobar another try yesterday.  I got a Carne Asada Taco to go.  I was given a little attitude on ordering just one taco - but that's all I wanted this time.  I asked about chips and salsa, as I didn't get them the first time I was there as anyone would expect from Mexican cuisine, but I was told that's separate.  Well, my one taco was more than $5 bucks so chips and salsa really should've been included.  I didn't get them.

I got my Steak Taco to go and got to eating it within a few minutes -- it wasn't really warm, the pinto beans (loose, not mashed or refried for ease of eating) were falling from every direction and the carne asada and pico de gallo were barely visible - NO NAPKINS INCLUDED!  My friend I was sitting near wondered when I'd become a vegetarian and why I was eating a runny, bean taco!  For $5 bucks, I got a bland, nasty pinto bean taco, with an unnoticeable garnish of carne asada and pico de gallo and no napkins...  NOT COOL AT ALL JACK.

I know I can sit down at a real Mexican restaurant with a waiter waiting on me, a full meal with great flavour and a live Mariachi Band for what I've wasted at Tacobar.  Not only is it not good food, it's a negative vibe also -- No real smiles when you walk in.  I've seen the owner leering around the shop probably wondering how things are going.  He should really ask the diners instead of staring/glaring at them, because so far his ideas are way off the mark.  You want an overpriced and seriously deficient Mexican meal? Try Tacobar.
author: Rocky S.

description:
The sun is out, people are out walking their dogs, and I can't stop checking out all the talent that keeps walking by.  One of the rare nice Saturday afternoons, and what better way to spend it than sitting outside and enjoying a meal, right?

I ordered a burro especial (carne asada) and an aguas frescas (watermelon).

The burrito: bland.  It wasn't disgusting but it wasn't great, either.  Kinda like that booty call who you hit up when it's 3AM and you're drunk and horny - it gets the job done but that's about it.  Much like the DL booty call, you don't tell your friends.  Parents/loved ones are out of the question.

The aguas frescas: if I'm going to put my masculinity on the line and drink a bright pink drink, it better be damned good. Disappointment. Not much flavor, but had a nice amount of fruit pulp. Think water with a small piece of Jolly Rancher blended in.  And a small piece of watermelon.   

This is San Francisco, for crying out loud... even if you don't want to hit up one of the many taquerias in the Mission, there are way better spots for Mexican.  Maybe there's a tax for having a quaint little shop on a foot traffic-heavy street.  I think that explains why I paid $15 for a tasteless burrito and glorified sugar water.
author: Gary L.

description:
I think this place is being panned pretty bad on Yelp. Tacos are decent, quesadillas are interesting (fat like a Burrito) and chips are high quality.  Horchata is good too. Can't beat the location or convenience!

As noted by others water glasses are ones the dentist uses (small)!

Here's something that should solve the issue around price: Reduce the price by $1 for everything on the menu (yes even the damn chips). Cuts into margins, but will make up in volume I think.
author: Sumit C.

description:
I wanted to check in and see if anything magical had happened at taco bar in the past month, so I stopped by for another inspection. Unfortunately, I don't have a lot of good news to report. As I mentioned previously, I don't mind paying more money for great food, but the prices have remained high and the quality has remained low.

Having tried the taco and the quesadilla already, I ventured into burrito territory. They are listed on the menu as "Burros," and I will say that removing the "-ito" from the end is an accurate description -- you certainly won't leave hungry if you order a burro. Unfortunately full and satisfied are not always the same thing.

The ingredients are promising... the beans and guac are flavorful and they were smart enough to leave the fried cheese mess off of the burrito, but the salsa here is about as lifeless as my 401(k). What's worse is that my burrito was served to me cold... and I mean REAL cold. I realize that some of the ingredients are refrigerated for freshness, but the heat from the warm ingredients should balance everything out and at least bring it to room temperature. Perhaps they thought I ordered a BRRRR-ito, instead.

It wasn't all bad news, however! Taco bar has upgraded to larger water cups! They are still smaller than I would like, but they are a lot more realistic than the shot glasses they had before. Thank you for listening!
author: Wayne F.

description:
I just started working on fillmore a few days ago and every time i walk by tacobar theres always a line. that has to mean its good, right? right!??!

Today I skipped breakfast and my lunch break was delayed for over an hour. I WAS STARVING!!! I took a quick peak into tacobar and was surprised to see no line (the other customers were all seated). i ordered my mexican food default, a carne asada burrito (close to $9 after tax).

you know how things tend to taste exceptionally good when youre starving? well, it didnt happen. the meat and the tortilla were dry! the burrito was so tasteless! UGH!! I was starving and I could barely stomach 1/4 of the burrito.  WHAT A SAD MEAL!!! :(
author: Stacy L.

description:
At last the Fillmore has cheap eats Mexican place that is GOOD!!

BTW Tamara you missed the point of my review. It was a joke(ever seen that Mervyn's commercial?). 

I too have been excited about the place opening. I am not an employee or any affiliation with the business and I think you owe these guys an apology.

They are now open as of today for lunches. They are super cool and the food is REALLY good.
author: Brian M.

description:
I love everything about this place!

The food is tasty, fresh and very nicely presented. And served on/in actual glassware! The staff is always smiling, very friendly and helpful. I hadn't noted that they were not super fast until I read the other reviews but it's completely worth the extra couple of minutes. 

I loooove that they serve grilled chicken as opposed to roasted. Maybe that's not traditionally Mexican but it really beats that reheated, roasted chicken flavor found in so many other places. 

The drinks are wonderful- both the alcoholic and non-alcoholic (try the fresh cucumber thing!!)
author: Gosia L.

description:
I should have read these reviews before I went! I was on Fillmore and just decided to stop by the new place. At first, I thought it was good. Expensive, yeah.. but hey, it is Fillmore st so I wasn't expecting it to be super cheap. I thought their tuna taco and shrimp tostada were pretty darn good. I went back a second time to try a burrito, and was super disappointed. I'm trying to be more "healthy" or something (why did I even bother having a burrito?) so I wanted one with no rice, sour cream, or cheese. I actually hate sour cream in burritos anyway. So when I get home and open my burrito, it has: sour cream, rice, and cheese. WTF? I told them at least three times what I wanted, and yet they managed to get everything I didn't want in there. For how expensive it is, you think they could try a little harder to get the effing order right. Also, they really skimped on the carnitas. 

To be fair though, someone said that chips and salsa were extra, but I got them for free when I ate there.. I don't know if that is normal though.

** Change **
I'm moving this from a 2 star to a 3 star review. After I posted my somewhat negative review, the owner sincerely apologized and offered us a gift certificate. I think that great customer service goes a long way, and they definitely get a point for apologizing and making it up to us. Thanks!
author: Ashley H.

description: Overall pretty good Mexican food if you are in a hurry. I've eaten here many times and have never been disappointed. But, I've never had my socks blown off either.
author: Dr. Trent G.

description: Get the Chicken Ques. with the baja lime sauce and a Pom Margarita. very good food! .
author: Summer M.

description:
Just ate here for lunch. 3 people, over $40 for lunch.

one fish taco---$5.75---lettuce was flavorless, tasted like iceberg from my middle school cafeteria.  Fish was moist---but that was about it's only redeeming feature.  Sauce was tepid; didn't finish it.

dining companions got the shrimp salad (what was that? straight up mayonnaise dumped on top of the otherwise reasonably fresh lettuce? And why were the shrimp dessicated? She didn't even finish them)

and the bean and cheese burrito.  Also not finished.

Jamaica aqua fresca was bitter tasting.

Really, this is the most stunningly mediocre meal, even before accounting for its cost, that I have had in 2010.

With Delfina Pizzaria across the street---never again.
For those who feel the need---numb yourself with liquor if you don't have to drive.
author: Roger W.

description:
Summary: Bland chicken taco, but deceptively tasty if (1) you drown it in the green salsa and (2) it's 4:45pm and you haven't eaten all day.  Sure beats gnawing your arm off!

I anticipated giving this place 1 star, as I was warned that it was craptastic/bland-tastic.  The taco was decent sized, seemed to weigh a lot.  I like to drench my tacos w/tons of salsa, so the taco actually had flavor to me. "Green salsa flavor", that is.  At the end, I decided to try a piece of the chicken on its own, without swimming in the green salsa.  And...it was indeed bland.  Even the pico de gallo included in the taco was bland--needs more cilantro, spices, onions, fire, FLAVOR! Funny how starving all day and dumping on verde salsa can cloud judgement and magically add a star to yelp review!

I was surprised there were actually a fair number of people eating here. But, they all looked tired, like they'd been shopping and starving all day, eating at an odd hour...

I have no desire to return (unless I happen to find myself on Fillmore & Cal, about to gnaw my arm off once again).
author: Caroline I.

description:
Yum yum yum!
Now I'm not a huge Mexican food eater as I'm a vegetarian (pescatarian) and my mouth hates spicy food...but TacoBar is consistently delicious.
I'm obsessed with their chips as well as their vegetarian burrito! The flavor is good and I love that there's not nasty grease dripping out of the bottom while taking a big bite.
author: Autumn H.

description:
I've only been there once, and will definitely go back and update my review, but I had to say:

The Tortilla Soup is delicious!

I wish there was a little bit more at 8$/cup (it should have been 5$ and then I could have gotten a taco to complement it), but wow, it was yummy. I added the salsas to the mix -- a smoky red and a sweeter green -- and it made it even more tasty. I wish the red had a little more bite to it, but, I'll deal.

This place is not cheap, but it is not that much  more expensive than Nick's Crispy/The Taco Shop at Underdogs, and at this location, it makes sense that it may be a quarter or so more. The service for carry out was quick, and I look forward to grabbing a taco or quesadilla in the not-too-distant future!
author: Annie F.

description:
Went in with very low expectations, walked out delighted!  This is what fillmore is missing, fast, yummy food that won't break the bank!  

All of the food was yummy, the staff was helpful, everything was quick, the place was clean.   I'll definitely go back!
author: Hillary S.

description:
Love it! The chicken tortilla soup is the best I've had, and the fish tacos I still schlep across town for. Come on people, step it up a little. If you want Mission style go to the Mission. If you want Mexico City Mexican - Go here. 
Authentic, yummy, and reasonably priced.
author: Lori L.

description: I ordered the vegetarian taco. It might have tasted better if I hadn't watched the guy preparing handle the tortillas with his bare hands and then scrape the vegetables off the spatula, also with his bare hands. I debated over whether to even eat it but I was really hungry. There's no way to know whether someone washes their hands after using the restroom and I'd lay odds he didn't. I thought it was standard to wear  plastic gloves when handling food.  I definitely won't be coming back.
author: Kathy D.

description:
I was so excited for Tacobar to open...as another yelper mentioned, there's not a lot of good cheap eats on Fillmore, especially that you can get quick and take to go.  And, unfortnuately, there's still no good cheap eats on Fillmore.  Tacobar is good, but crazy expensive!  I've been probably 4 or 5 times now, and I get sticker shock every time.  You would think I'd learn my lesson, but it's like I'm in denail, like it's going to be different THIS time.  But, it's not.  Burritos are 10 bucks (well, only $7.75, but that's if you get it without all the good stuff), tacos are $6 each, and you don't get any chips and salsa with it.  One time I asked for chips, they said, "chips and salsa?" and I said sure, and 5 bucks later, I had my chips and salsa.  It's rediculous.  I think I could get over the prices if they would at least give me the standard chips and salsa with it.  


It's bascially only good if you are starving, don't feel like cooking and want something decent to eat.  Just be prepared to spend way more than you ever have on a pretty basic burrito.

Oh, the one great thing they do have is the tequila ice cream - awesome.
author: H S.

description: This place is pricey but the baja pescado tacos are so worth it.. they are UHH-MAA-ZING lol try them i'm sure you will all feel the same. I work close by and since one of my co-workers turned me on I am addicted. Expect me here on my lunch breaks they are really that good
author: nicole i.

description:
I tried this place for the first time this afternoon. I ordered two carne asada tacos, and was surprised that they were $4.85 apiece. With a drink the order came to over $13.

The tacos were relatively large, filled with pinto beans, meat and some pico de gallo. Unfortunately the tacos were bland, the meat and pico de gallo had very little flavor and I mostly tasted the pinto beans. I poured on a generous amount of their house salsa, but it didn't add much flavor either. 

I was very disappointed, if I return I may try one of their burritos which are a little more reasonably priced (around $8), but there are other better and cheaper places in the neighborhood so I won't be hurrying back.
author: Matt S.

description:
This was an unexpected good find. I had always passed by this restaurant and on a recent Sunday afternoon, after craving some Mexican food, I decided to finally give it a try. 

The mahi mahi grilled tacos were delicious - albeit a little small. The tortilla chips were fresh & crunchy. Both of these items paired well with the Negro Modelo.  Also offered on the drink menu is sangria, which I'd like to try.

It wasn't a cheap meal, but it was worth it - I think I'd definitely go back for a quick bite.
author: Heidi B.

description:
With all the hype over Tacolicious in the Marina you would never know there is a better alternative for quality Mexican street food just up the hill.  Tacobar gets almost everything right - good selection, quality meats, fresh flavorful salsas, and homemade tortilla chips.

Unfortunately, the restaurant location used to be an old La Salsa, leading many to believe it is a similar replacement - not the case.  In a city that struggles to offer Mexican food beyond uninspired taqueria fare, Tacobar is a welcome addition.

Only negative - the guacamole needs improvement.
author: Mathew S.

description: I needed some tacos and this place didn't disappoint. I got the cucumber line agua fresca and three tacos. The chicken was ok, steak better than most and the Baja Pescado was legendary. Cabbage slaw, ancho salsa and Baja line sauce were an amazing combo!  Next time I'm near I'll definitely stop by again!!
author: D S.

description:
I loved this new edition to fillmore street.  I ordered the baja pescado burritto "especial" and it blew me away, so fresh and tasty!!!  The food came with a big basket of chips and I sat outside and enjoyed the sun while I ate.
